Description:
The Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (UCKG) is a Christian Ministry and registered charity (1043985) dedicated to helping people live life to the fullest ‚Äî physically, emotionally and spiritually.

Over the years, we have reached such a diverse group of people that our work has touched millions across over 170 countries. Their unique stories remind us that with the right kind of help and support, the most heartbreaking stories can become tomorrow‚Äôs inspirational ones. In these testing times, we are determined to do more. Support us
Title: Graci 's PTB 2021 Soup Kitchen/Food Bank page

Description:
VIRTUAL ART EXHIBITION EXTENDED UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30TH -

And that means more time for us to raise more much-needed funds for the inspirational London's Air Ambulance, a charity providing lifesaving treatment for the capital‚Äôs most critically injured patients - fast. They've treated more than 40,000 seriously ill patients since 1989. They are true #londonheroes. You've probably seen their bright red helicopter racing across the London skies.

London's Air Ambulance rely on public donations and fundraising to keep flying.The 'A River Runs Through It' artists would love your support to help us beat the ¬£1500 we raised at last year's show.


Here's how you can help us this year: VISIT, WIN PRIZES, SIGN UP!


VISIT OUR VIRTUAL REALITY OXO GALLERY and see our new London-art collections from until September 30th (www.ariverrunsthroughit.london), follow us on Instagram @ariverrunsthroughit2020 find out more). The artists will donate 10% of all sales to London's Air Ambulance.


DONATE TO WIN art and great London-themed prizes in our RIVER RAFFLE runnning throughout the show.

Just ¬£3 per entry, with no limit on the number of entries- the more you enter, the better your chances of winning! We will automatically enter you in the raffle when you donate through JustGiving, one entry for each ¬£3 donation - all we need is your email to let you know if you've won. 

Prizes include meals at London restaurants, trips on Thames Rockets  boats, vouchers for London theatres, training sessions, art work from  the artists and much more...                  


WATCH TABISH KHAN'S ENTERTAINING ART TALK AGAIN. Donate ¬£5 and we'll send you the link to watch the talk again, with all profits going to London's Air Ambulance.

Join Londonist art critic, ArtCan Trustee and columnist for FAD magazine Tabish Khan to hear about "The Artist Who Ate A Corgi & Other Stories‚Äù - London‚Äôs history through Art. Tabish's talks are seriously popular, so make sure you book tickets as soon as you can.

And watch the very special PRIVATE VIEW again, hosted on Zoom by the Londonist's art critic Tabish Khan (@londonartcritic). Tabish takes you on a virtual VIP tour and chats to the artists. You'll also have an opportunity to hear about their incredible work from the London's Air Ambulance crew themselves. Visit www.ariverrunsthroughit.london to see the PV again.


This year's A River Runs Through It artists are LoveJordan, Ella Friere, Michael Wallner, Susan Bunn and Emma Reynolds. We're so grateful for any support you can give us and London's Air Ambulance.


ABOUT THE EXHIBITION

A River Runs Through It is an artistic celebration of London, hosted
by a collective of London artists every September, attracting more than 16,000 visitors to gallery@oxo in the last five years.

This year, due to the pandemic, we are hosting the show in a superb virtual reality Oxo gallery, alongside a fantastic programme of online talks, meet the artist and instagram events, short films with London heroes, our popular River Raffle, and more...

And that's where we really need your help.

Without the regular 6,000 visitors to a 'real gallery' this year we're
working even harder to attract more people to view the show and in turn raise even more money for London's Air Ambulance. We'd love to top last year's total of ¬£1,500.

Find out more about the show and the programme of events @ariverrunsthroughit2020 on Instagram.

(Email: ariverrunsthroughit2020@gmail.com)

Big thanks from Jonny, Sam, Ella, Michael, Susan and Emma

Description:
WE NEED TO SAVE ALL THE KITTIES!

 There are some horrible mean people don't like kitties..

That‚Äôs why we need the Cat Protection, an organisation that helps rescue and rehome poor unwanted kitties as well as educates people about cats and cats wellbeing. Both of my cute (-ish) kitties in my home are rescue cats and without organisations like Cats Protection both would have been left out in the wilderness to fend for themselves.

People like Cats Protection help find them, nurse them back to health and rehome them while not asking much in return. Because of them I have two little floofy madams that bring warmth, character and sometimes mice into our home.

So on Saturday 30th October we will be celebrating these wonderful
people and help try raise some money and awareness for them.

We will be cooking, playing games, chatting about cats and (hopefully) be joined by the ladies of the house themselves.

(Menus and games will be finalised closer to the time)

So pwease if you can donate some mones for these lovely peeps, or even just tune in for a minutes, everything you do to help will be MASSIVELY appreciated!

Title: Helen's page

Description:
My childhood friend, Sharon Riley, turned 50 in December last year but I was unable to celebrate this special birthday with her due to the pandemic. I also turned 50 this year and Sharon & I were looking forward to marking our milestone birthdays together with our families.  Sadly, this was not to be, as Sharon unexpectedly died in April of this year, two months before my birthday. She had started to feel unwell in December but put a lot of her symptoms (exhaustion, lack of appetite and nausea) down to the menopause.  Unknown to us all, Sharon's symptoms were something more sinister and in March she was admitted to hospital with concerns about her liver.  She was tested for hepatitis A, B and C  but results were all negative.  She was also tested for Hepatitis E ( I had never even heard of this), which also proved to be negative.  Even though all her symptoms were pointing to liver failure, the CT scan showed no scarring or enlargement of her liver.  She was not transferred to a liver specialist hospital (such as the Royal Free in London) as her case was considered not acute enough.  The doctors were optimistic that her liver would heal and she wouldn't need a transplant. The family were advised to be patient as her recovery could prove to be a slow journey.  However, Sharon was in hospital for just one month, due to the pandemic, she was unable to be visited by friends and family and died on April 13th. For all of us that knew Sharon, there will always be so many unanswered questions and what ifs. What we do know is, that even though Sharon was tested for the known types of Hepatitis, there are other types out there that are still unknown. The British Liver Trust provides advice and information to patients and families; campaigns and works with healthcare professionals to improve early diagnosis and patient care; raises awareness of how to look after your liver and supports research. There are over 100 types of liver conditions; some are rare and others can be prevented. 20% of the population is at risk of liver disease, there are many causes we still don‚Äôt know about. 

I have so many beautiful memories of Sharon, ones that make me smile and some that make me laugh out loud.  One such memory is dragging Sharon running with me, along Zig Zag Lane, wearing her 'daps' from Woolworth's, both of us getting the giggles and  her complaining the whole time of a stitch.  She never came running with me again. I was very proud of her though when she took up running as a mum in a concerted effort to get fit later in life.

As I run my first half marathon through Hackney, my thoughts will be with you Sharon and the forty years of memories we shared together!

Thank you for your support, and please don‚Äôt forget to Gift Aid your donation if you are a UK taxpayer.
Title: Kirsten's page

Description:
For around 18 months Hannah has been planning to get her hair cut to donate to The Little Princess Trust, to be made into a wig for another child. Initially, Hannah had around the minimum amount of hair, around 7 inches to spare. However, she's waited and waited for it to grow so her donation will now be nearer to the preferred 12 inch length. Anyone who has ever brushed or combed Hannah's hair, will know how much patience and determination she has shown.  At last, the time has come and Hannah is ready to donate her hair. However we need to raise around  ¬£380 to cover the cost of her hair being made into a wig  that can be given free of charge to a child who has undergone treatment for cancer. Every donation, regardless of the amount will help Hannah closer to her target. Thank you so much.

Description:
Thanks for visiting our fundraiser site. 

Imagine being homeless, having no option to self isolate or stock up on supplies, with many support services you were relying on closing down. Alongside homeless people there will be thousands more people who end up in food poverty, families who were relying on free school meals and those who have just been made redundant due to the crisis.

Since Friday 20th March Social Bite has re-purposed its entire organisation to create a nationwide food delivery service. Their kitchens, cafes and teams have been entirely re-deployed to produce and deliver food and supplies to those who need them most for the duration of this outbreak. They are working with more than 50 partners to ensure that food and essential supplies can reach the following people

- Homeless People

- Families that were relying on free school meals and now have no access

-Those who have been made redundant due to the crisis and are in food poverty

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre supporting the campaign at Harajuku Kitchen. Through your support of our takeaway service we will be supporting many vulnerable people across Scotland.
Title: Harajuku Kitchen for  Social Bite 4000 meal a day fundraiser

Description:
For 2020, Fudge Kitchen is delighted to be supporting the wonderful work of the Yorkshire Air Ambulance (YAA). Each year we select a chosen charity from a list of nominations put forward by our staff from all over the UK and dedicate a year‚Äôs fundraising to their cause. This year‚Äôs cause is like all of them, close to our hearts, but has special significance to the Assistant Manager of our Bath shop, Tia Hancy, whose Dad was rescued by emergency services, including the Yorkshire Air Ambulance after a farming accident in 2013.

The Yorkshire Air Ambulance is a lifeline for rural and less connected communities, being able to reach the scene of an emergency more quickly than traditional services. Yorkshire Air Ambulance (YAA) is an independent rapid response charity, which has carried more than 8,000 people in its nearly 20-year history. It needs to raise ¬£12,000 each day to keep its two helicopters in the air and maintained - equivalent to ¬£4.4 million each year.

Without any direct government funding, the only help the charity receives is through the secondment of its paramedics from the Yorkshire Ambulance Service NHS Trust. So, it is with great pleasure that Fudge Kitchen can support the work of this amazing charity throughout 2020.
Title: Fudge Kitchen Annual Charity 2020 - Yorkshire Air Ambulance

Description:
Brewhouse & Kitchen at Poole, Bournemouth and Southborough in Dorset are support RNLI lifeguards this summer by hosting quiz and live music events, whilst raising vital donations for the RNLI. 

RNLI Lifeguards respond to the thousands of incidents that happen every year along coastlines in the UK and Ireland. Our lifeguards keep beachgoers safe by spotting the dangers and preventing accidents before they happen, as well as responding instantly if they occur. That's why providing our lifeguard crews with first-class training is vital. Lifeguards are qualified in lifesaving and casualty care, and are highly trained and fit. They maintain a level of fitness, which allows them to swim 200m in under 3¬Ω minutes, and run 200m on sand in under 40 seconds.

But there's still training to be done. Your donation, supporting Brewhouse & Kitchen, will help fund this essential training, when visits to the south east beaches are higher than ever.

Thank you for your support.
Title: Brewhouse & Kitchen Supports RNLI Lifeguards

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page! 

My name is Charlotte Kitchen and I am running the London marathon on 2nd October 2022. I am aiming to raise 2,200 pounds to help fund Save the Children's incredible work. 

Save the Children holds a special place in my heart as it was the first organisation that I fundraised for back in 2016. I will always be grateful for Save the Children as its where I found a new passion and determination to influence change, forge out a career in the fundraising sector and make lifelong friends. 

At this time I fundraised on a vaccination campaign aiming to reach the final 1/5 of children that didn't have the access to life saving vaccinations. 

Healthcare shouldn't be a privilege, yet every year millions of children die from preventable diseases, in fact 50% of under 5 deaths are caused by infectious diseases. 

Save the children not only are influencing change at a governmental level, but also creating long term sustainable solutions by helping communities strengthen their healthcare systems, training local healthcare professionals as well as delivering life saving vaccinations. 

Please give what you can to this incredible case!

Title: Rowan's Birthday

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

An update:

When I pledged to complete this challenge, as a family we were living with the daily loss that Alzheimer‚Äôs Disease creates. To no longer be remembered by a loved one was cruel and heartbreaking. I couldn‚Äôt stop the damage that Alzheimer‚Äôs Disease was doing to my family but I decided that I could try to stop it happening to others. I pledged in April to raise as much as I could in honour of my lovely Father-in-Law, because although he may no longer have remembered who I was to him, I promised I would never forget who he still was to me. 

Sadly, but thankfully peacefully, ‚ÄòDad‚Äô passed away on 23rd June. I always knew that there was a chance when I pledged to complete this run in 4 weeks time that Dad wouldn‚Äôt be here with us to show him the medal I hope to earn. It makes my training sessions very emotional as I think of him as I run but I am determined, however slowly, to complete this 21km run in his honour on 12th September.

Thank you for any donation you can make, it will be hugely appreciated by so many who are, or will sadly one day be, sharing our heart breaking experiences. I hope for a day where no one suffers due to Alzheimer‚Äôs Disease. I would love to smash my target, that I never expected to almost reach, and support Alzheimer‚Äôs Research UK in their vital work.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and for all of your love and support since we lost ‚ÄòDad‚Äô.

Jules xx

With SNP, help us to support Lonely Orphans as they provide essential support and care all over the world for orphans and those in dire need. There are over 153 million orphan children around the world. 

Every day, an estimated 5,700 more children become orphans due to war, natural disaster, poverty, disease, stigma and medical needs. SaveTheOrphans provides long term support for orphans and vulnerable children for 365 days of the year, allowing you to leave your legacy.


Focus areas:

Description:
Hi Everyone!

I'm trying to raise some money to donate to Women's Aid this Christmas. This fantastic charity is so incredibly important to me and the work they do is invaluable. 

The organisation works to help women and children suffering from domestic abuse. 

Just some of the things they provide:

  • much needed support to women in need
  • campaign for changes to laws to help protect women
  • help survivors of domestic violence get back on their feet
  • conduct research 
  • training and qualifications to give support workers the tools required to help women in need. 

With the ongoing pandemic, their work is absolutely crucial with many women and children being forced to lock down with their abusers and being isolated even further from friends and family. 

Women's Aid provided support to me at a time when I needed it most and I am forever grateful. Now I am in a far happier and stable time in my life I would like to donate to the charity that helped me get here. 

Thank you,

Rosie
Title: Christmas Fundraiser for Women's Aid

Description:
Due to the current restrictions, unfortunately only 14 people are able to attend the funeral of Kathleen Kitchen, the most wonderful wife, mum, grandma and great-grandma. Due to this, there are no collection boxes available for those who wish to make a donation. 

As a family, we're still so shocked and utterly devastated to be doing this, but in her memory, if you would like to make a donation, we have chosen 'Children with Cancer' as the charity who we're sure gran would've loved to have seen benefit from your contribution.

Gran adored children, and she always had a special place in her heart for those who were disabled, had learning difficulties or were terminally ill, including those with cancer. We're sure this would've touched her heart, like the so many hearts she touched during the precious time we had with her.

CharityName: Cancer Research UK, Marie Curie & The Swimathon Foundation
Description:
Swimathon 2021 is here! Thousands of swimmers will be heading down to their local pool between Friday 10th September and Sunday 12th September to complete their challenge, and raise money for our two amazing charity partners.

Cancer Research UK, the worlds leading cancer charity is dedicated to saving lives through funding research to help prevent, diagnose and treat cancer. Cancer Research UK are the only charity fighting over 200 cancer types but don't receive any government funding for their work, so their progress is all thanks to the support of people like you.

Marie Curie provides expert care, guidance and support for people living with any terminal illness, and their families. Around 2,100 Marie Curie Nurses work day and night, in peoples homes all over the UK, providing hands-on care to people when they need it most.

Together we can really make a difference. We invite our swimmers to tell their story to help spread awareness and raise vital funds for these two incredible causes.

If you would like to find out more about Swimathon 2021, please visit - https://swimathon.org/
Title: Swimathon 2021

Description:
Across The Body Shop at Home we are fundraising for Children on the Edge; to bring hope, life, colour and fun to children living on the edge of society.

Children on the Edge was sparked into life by Dame Anita Roddick over 30 years ago. Not long after this The Body Shop At Home began to support them. Children on the Edge supports over 15,000 of the worlds most marginalised children to realise their rights. In India, Uganda, Bangladesh, Myanmar and Lebanon they help create protective environments where children can thrive.

In 2021 our support can help Dalit children in India to access education, develop community activism and grow in confidence; helping to break the cycle of discrimination.
Title: Kelly 's Team Nova

Description:
As a lot of people know, I'm very proud of my long hair, but it's been pointed out on a number of occasions that the Little Princesses will benefit more from having it, so it's getting donated! On Friday 18th it's getting tied up, lopped off and put in an envelope to be made into a wig, and I'd love it if people were able to throw some pennies this way. I know it's been a hell of a year and no one is particularly flush at the moment, but anything will certainly help out!

----

When a child loses their hair to cancer or another condition, we'll be there with a free, real hair wig to help restore their confidence and identity. We won't stop until the research that we fund ends childhood cancer forever. Promise.Please visit us at www.littleprincesses.org.uk to find out how you can help us give young people back what cancer takes away.The Trust relies solely on the efforts of enthusiastic community fundraisers. We receive no formal funding. Please help to raise money for us so that we can help more families.
Title: Matthew's Have Yourself a Hairy Little Christmas!

Description: I'm swimming the equivalent distance of the English Channel (22 miles) in my local pool in support of Diabetes UK. There are 4.8 million people living with diabetes in the UK, the complications of which lead to over 500 premature deaths every week. That's why I'll be lowering my goggles and clocking up the lengths to raise money to fund research and support those living with diabetes, such as my lovely friends Anna Yeomans & Tom Hennessey, who are both type 1. I‚Äôm hoping to complete my challenge in a similar time to the first person to successfully swim the Channel, Captain Matthew Webb, who did it in 21 hours and 45 minutes. Like Webb, I‚Äôll be swimming the 22 miles breaststroke. Wish me luck and please support my challenge by donating what you can!
Title: Emily's Channel Swim Challenge

Description:
My children created one of these Christmas trees a few years ago in aid of cancer research due to our family member Dave and others fighting this horrible disease, the tree was a great success and we raised over ¬£300. Sadly Our Dave since has lost his battle with cancer  last July. We have decided as a tribute in his memory we will do another tree for Christmas and we are asking people to buy a Bauble minimum donation of ¬£1.00  and put your Christmas message on and we will put it on our tree whether in memory of someone you've lost  or a Christmas message we will hang it up  and keep you posted with photos through  this page and Facebook. Donations will go to Bolton Hospice who were a great support  to Dave and our family  in the last few weeks of Dave's illness .  Dave always liked to fund raise for these great causes and will be proud that we are doing this in his memory again.

Merry Christmas

Thank you for your kind Donations

From

 All of Dave's Family

Xxx
Title: Buy a bauble in memory of Dave

CharityName: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
Description:
This year I have signed up for my 1st of 3 events for The Stratford Half Marathon for the 2nd year in a row in memory of my friend Andrew Forster, who sadly in January 2016 aged 30 lost his short and brave fight against blood cancer. Having raised a fantastic ¬£768.10 last year for lymphoma, this year, having been in regular contact with Andrew's family they have requested any donations to go to Great Ormond Street Hospital, as the charity was very close to Andrew, and in particular during his short fight felt more concerned about the children in GOSH than himself. Any donations will be able to go in Andrew's own charity account.

Thank you.

Michael

Title: Andy's 2018 RBLR 1000 mile Iron Butt Motor Cycle Ride

Description:
On the 16th September 2018 I will be setting off from Diss in Norfolk (UK) in my 'Big White Berlingo Car' on a long drive to Jerusalem.

I‚Äôve booked one night in a hotel and a ferry ticket to Cherbourg and that‚Äôs it. The rest of the journey will be organised as I go along. My aim is to be in Jerusalem by the end of November and back home in the UK for Christmas (I‚Äôve promised my family). That‚Äôs roughly 10,000  kilometres in just over three months. I‚Äôve avoided a detailed plan in preference for spontaneity but the headlines are I will be travelling out through France, Italy, Greece and Turkey, and returning via the Balkans, then central and Western Europe. Unfortunately I will be forced to fly to Israel from Turkey as the land route either through Libya or Syria is too dangerous at the moment.

I will be generally sleeping in the back of the car, with
seats removed.  I use my mum‚Äôs old 1970 sofa cushion for a bed, and it serves the purpose well. Other than a map, a washing up bowl, a kettle, basic car repair kit and half a dozen changes of clothing that‚Äôs it. I‚Äôm doing everything on the ultra-cheap.

Why- 

Firstly it‚Äôs for myself. I don‚Äôt feel right unless I take on a few big trips a year especially now that I‚Äôm retired. But it‚Äôs also to raise money for my favourite charity 'Become' (http://www.becomecharity.org.uk/),which is the leading charity helping young people coming out of the care system and starting adult life. In my career as a psychiatric nurse I encountered many people for whom this transition had gone badly wrong. This is common. 'Become' works with care leavers to help them establish a firm footing, as they take their first steps toward independent living

What equips me for
this? -

 I am a sixty year old overweight, rheumatic retired psychiatric nurse with a lifelong love of independent travel using local transport, walking, hitch hiking or driving ordinary vehicles. 

There has been scores of these trips but just taking the best this hobby has taken me on over 10,000 miles worth of trips by motorhome around the USA. More recently I have travelled by long distance bus and ferry boat around Argentina (including Northern Patagonia) and the nearer parts of Uruguay. 

I spent a month travelling around India by train using second class carriages, that is those used by the poorest local people. Despite a general lack of fitness I‚Äôve walked the first hundred miles of the Via Egnatia, a rough country track which follows a Roman road across Albania. Each spring for the last five years I have walked 100-200 miles  on the ancient pilgrimage route, the Camino Sangtiago de Compestela that runs from France to Galicia in North-Western Spain. 

During the 1980‚Äôs and early 1990‚Äôs I lived In South Africa and travelled extensively in neighbouring countries (Lesotho, Swaziland, Zambia, Botswana, and Zimbabwe).

I enjoy this kind of thing, and have been doing it
since I was a teenager. I do my best to be around local people, talk to strangers and find out how they live. I stay well clear of any tourist hubs and instead hop between smaller towns and immerse myself in local life for a few days. I‚Äôm the resilient type and tend to find a way of getting through or past obstacles.

On this trip I will be posting a daily blog and Facebook updates where ever possible. Sponsors will be able to follow my journey through these.

I have been very fortunate in my life but I've known many people who grew up in care, and then failed to find the help and support they needed when the time came to leave. Often they were ill equipped to cope alone and went on to have serious mental health or drug and alcohol problems. The charity 'Become' is all about helping such people with this transition. I've supported them for a number of years through personal donations , and have seen the quality of help they provide. Its really all about improving the life opportunities of people for whom things can...and  often go badly wrong  That's why I have chosen to undertake this trip to benefit 'Become'.

All the costs of travel are being met by myself and a separate network of sponsors. No money raised for 'Become' will come to me.

Title: Chris's Kitchs dryathlon

Description:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my page.

As some of you know, I turn 22 on the 21st September 2018. And instead of gifts, I am asking for donations through this page in support of Mind, the mental health charity. 

I have recently moved back to Suffolk, so see it as fitting that I specifically as for donations in support of Suffolk Mind.  

One of the many and most pressing struggles that people face are issues with their mental health.  This is especially high with young people, please see the below statistics that I have taken from: https://www.mentalhealth.org.uk/statistics/mental-health-statistics-children-and-young-people

 -  20% of adolescents may experience a mental health problem in any given year.

-  50% of mental health problems are established by age 14 and 75% by age 24.


-  10% of children and young people (aged 5-16 years) have a clinically diagnosable mental problem, yet 70% of children and adolescents who experience mental health problems have not had appropriate interventions at a sufficiently early age.

These statistics are incredibly scary, and as someone who relies on mental health services, I can honestly say that without charities such as Mind, the NHS would simply not cope.  The availability of mental health services in this country are very poor, with far more people reaching out for help than the system has availability for.  No one should have to face their mental health battle alone, and I want to help wherever possible.  

Mind will always hold a place in my heart, as without them I wouldn't have been/ be able to access the help that I need.  

I cannot thank everyone who has supported me over the last few years enough, as without external support I wouldn't be able to get better, support of friends and family, as well as mental health services, are vital to recovery. 

Thank you again, Suffolk Mind, and me, thank you from the bottom of our hearts for your support for better mental health. 

Emily

Title: Jim Kitchen & Sam Salt's Wedding

Description:
This year, instead of Christmas presents we‚Äôre asking friends and loved ones to help us raise money for the Fetal Medicine Foundation and the amazing research and training they provide into areas such as early diagnosis of fetal abnormalities and prevention of stillbirth.

This year we experienced first hand the incredible work they do and we just want to show our gratitude by giving something back.

If you‚Äôve found yourself here you will know that on 23rd July this year I gave birth to our daughter Cassi. You‚Äôll also know that our Cassi wasn‚Äôt meant for this world and I gave birth to her knowing this. I can‚Äôt begin to explain what it feels like going through labour, for the first time, knowing your child has died before their life has truly begun. Our journey was one of utter joy then devastating sadness. I still find it difficult to even put into words. But what we do know is that we desperately want something good to come out of all of this and that‚Äôs why we‚Äôre asking, you to help us raise money for the Fetal Medicine Foundation.

So, if whilst you‚Äôre buying presents, cards and food treats for Christmas you can spare a few of your pennies for this amazing charity we would be immensely grateful.

Much love Naomi and Simon üíï

Title: Ellie braves the chop

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit the Companion 40 for 40 Club fundraising page. 

Sue Ryder Wheatfields appealed towards the end of last year for 40 Leeds businesses to sign up to commit to helping them raise ¬£40,000 for the hospice in 2018, which is their 40th anniversary year.

It costs ¬£11,000 a day to run the hospice, which has 18 beds, 271 staff and volunteers and eight hospice shops. They have cared for a total of 40,000 patients.

Companion's target is to raise ¬£1,000 this year from a number of fundraising activities; we're planning a Bake Off competition, a Halloween tombola, a Yorkshire 3 Peaks Challenge and loads more!

¬£1,000 could pay for:

  • a syringe driver to give constant pain relief for patients
  • a bed for two days of inpatient care for a hospice patient
  • 10 individual visits by community nurses

Please help us to reach our fundraising target and support the Wheatfields team in their fantastic work.

Title: In Memory of Nigel Kitchen

Description:
Hello!

My name is Sam, and I'm [trying to reframe my coping mechanisms away from someone who may describe themselves as] an alcoholic.

In September 2019, I took part in a 24 hour hike across the Scottish Highlands to fundraise for Mind. I smashed it, and raised ¬£1145 (https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/sam-kitchen2).

Since then, people have asked me what my next challenge is. Could train and run a marathon, travel to other parts of the earth to experience extreme temperatures and weathers, could go volunteer in other countries to build shelters and do general good people things.

Or, I could learn how to sit with my own company, regardless of how much I want to block out the realities of life. I think I'd rather climb Mount Everest, thanks.

I'm fundraising for Samaritans as we all just need someone who can listen to us, sit with us where we are without judgement, help us find acceptance and continue to live life to the best of our ability.

This wont be easy. I'm fully expecting to slip up from time to time. Please stick with me through this, friends - I'm gonna need you!

Love, Sam xxx
Title: Sam goes sober for January & maybe beyond?

Title: Paul Kitchen & Samuel Arnold's Wedding

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Marie Curie is the UK‚Äôs leading end of life charity.  They provide frontline nursing and hospice care, a free support line and a wealth of information and support on all aspects of dying, death and bereavement.  In these uncertain times, raising money to help our local nurses makes such a difference. Every penny means they can provide more care ‚Äì at home and in our hospices. The money we raise is desperately needed at the moment as coronavirus has forced the Marie Curie team to cancel many of their fundraising activities. 

Marie Curie is a charity that's very close to our hearts here at The Kitchen, as Kate explains: "My mum was diagnosed with stage 4 ovarian cancer in 2014.  She had around three years of treatment and also developed Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma before receiving a terminal diagnosis.  My sister and I were able to nurse her at home during her final illness and this meant so much to mummy and to us as a family.  In the final 3 weeks of her life we had support every night from the nurses at Marie Curie.  They didn't just care for mummy, they cared for us all.  They calmed our fears, allowed us to rest and provided so much comfort to us all during those lonely night-time hours.  They truly were our angels. 

So this Christmas at The Kitchen, we are holding a virtual Raffle Extravaganza to raise money for this wonderful cause.  

We have a great selection of 15+ prizes to be won, including hampers and vouchers from many of our local businesses. Along with each prize, each winner will receive a ¬£20 Kitchen voucher as well.  These prizes will be shared on our social media pages over the coming days and the draw will take place on Tuesday 22nd December! 

Tickets are priced at 1 for ¬£2, 3 for ¬£5 or 6 for ¬£10 and can be purchased in The Kitchen or by making a donation to this page - we will email you your ticket number(s) within 48 hours of entry.   Please remember to leave your name in the optional 'Your Name' box so that we can contact you should you be one of our lucky winners! You will still have the option to 'Hide' your name from public view should you wish. 

Thank you for supporting this wonderful cause,

The Kitchen Team xx
Title: Raffle Extravaganza in aid of Marie Curie

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My plan is to complete 1,000 miles on my motor cycle in under 24hrs in memory of my brother and sister-in-law and while doing so raise funds for Wakefield Hospice who looked after my brother and sister-in law.  The world has gone through a lot of late but we must not forget people and places like Wakefield Hospice who rely on donations.

After lockdown I will ride the Northern clockwise route of the Iron Butt Association to Wick and back in Northern Scotland. For verification I will take photographs at the six check points on departure, Birch Services M62, Fort William services , Wick services , Edinburgh services and Berwick on Tweed A1 services and on arrival back home, of both mileage, receipts and time from all petrol station stops. All in line with the Iron Butt Association rules. I will pay for my my own fuel while completing the challenge and whatever I spend on fuel I will match to Wakefield Hospice.

No date has been set as I will wait for a dry weekend and then set off on my challenge very early on a Saturday morning returning early hours of Sunday morning.  

If lockdown continues the challenge will run into 2021.

Thank you for your support.

Andy Kitchen.
Title: Andy's page

Description:
This June, the TRIBE community is coming together to take on an epic Scottish trail: The John Muir Way.

We are a 4 man team who all have at least one thing in common, we have either served or are still serving in the REME, the team consists of Stu (Late Entry Officer and organiser), Gaz (Direct Entry Officer and Army Commando), Smudge (Serving NCO and Airborne soldier) and Nick (REME Veteran). None of us have ever taken part in an event like this before and regardless of our background we will all find this challenging.

Taking place on the longest day of the year, we will relay through the day into the night. We will push the limits of human endurance and run a 228km relay across the John Muir way in Scotland from Helensburgh on the west coast to Dunbar on the East coast, each runner will have to run a total of between 50km and 64km in 4 stages of anything from 7km to 24km. There will always be 1 runner on the route whilst the other 3 move by car to set exchange points, this is repeated until we finish some 24 hours after we start. With a combination of running varied distances and being crammed in to a car between legs on top of little to no sleep, this will test us all physically and mentally.

There are an estimated 136,000 people living in slavery in the UK (Global Slavery Index 2019). That's more than two victims for every thousand people in the country. This needs to stop.

TRIBE Freedom Foundation was inspired by Run for Love - an epic 1,000 mile journey to raise ¬£250k and set up the first home for trafficked children in the UK. We work by raising awareness of trafficking and supporting frontline projects to fight modern slavery. We empower the TRIBE community to create an impact.

Let's do this!
Title: My TRIBE Relay Across Scotland Fundraising Page!

Description: I'm taking on Swim22, from 22 July to 22 October in support of Diabetes UK. There are 4.8 million people living with diabetes in the UK, the complications of which lead to over 500 premature deaths every week. That's why I'll be lowering my goggles and clocking up the lengths to raise money to fund research breakthroughs and support those living with diabetes. Wish me luck and please support my challenge by hitting the donate button.

Dementia UK's Admiral Nurses work alongside people with dementia, and their families: giving them one-to-one support, expert guidance and practical solutions. The unique dementia expertise an Admiral Nurse brings is a lifeline. It helps families to live more positively with dementia in the present, and to face the challenges of tomorrow with more confidence and less fear.

Thank you so much for helping pay tribute to my loved-one by helping other families facing dementia.

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
Many of you have called, emailed or messaged to ask about how we are coping with COVID-19 and the impact it has had on our organisation. Firstly, let me say thank you for the outpouring of support we've received. It's always a heart-warming feeling to know that we have so many incredible supporters. 

Last week, in light of the Coronavirus, we made the difficult decision to offer a takeaway-only food service to guests rather than their usual sit-down meal. As most of you know, we take a huge amount of pride in the fact that we offer not just a warm meal to our guests, but also a safe and warm space off the streets for them for the hours they're with us. As we considered the health risks we decided that it would be prudent to only offer a takeaway food service for the foreseeable future.

Absolutely any donation will have a huge impact on our services. Thank you for helping us support the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate in London!

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
The American Soup Kitchen (SK) on Tottenham Court Road has been providing food to the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate everyday for over 30 years. With the recent COVID-19 related lockdown it witnessed a collapse in its corporate funding. We would like to assist them in raising some money as a result. 

At a time when most other soup kitchens have had to close, the SK has been serving approximately 150 meals per day. They have implemented social distancing measures such as take away meals and ensuring 2 metre distancing between Guests. 

The SK has adopted the government‚Äôs guidelines for charities in the work that it does to protect its staff, volunteers and beneficiaries.

For instance the SK has taken steps to protect its staff, volunteers and guests by enforcing social distancing using ground markers and security personnel and by insisting upon the use of sanitizers provided and by asking guests to move on once they‚Äôve collected their hot and cold food parcels.  

We are writing to ask for your help by way of ¬£15 per month for the next three months - so ¬£45 to help see the SK through the worst of this global crisis. Our aim is to get 100 funders on board in this way which will help cover monthly running costs for about 50 Guests until corporate funders return post the lockdown. Over the last ten years we know many of you have supported the fantastic work of the SK, sometimes as volunteers and at other times through donations of food and clothing.  

A massive THANK YOU from us and from the SK ! 

 Paliwal  & Maru Families

So my beard has been with me since time began and many of you have said in the past "im gonna cut it off in your sleep".  Well here's your chance to help my beard earn some money for a worthy cause.

So in the words of Bob Geldoff ‚ÄúGive us your f***ing money‚Äù ;-)ill

I'll be cutting it off on my shift at the Soup Kitchen on Nov 21st.

From 12th November 2018, the Newbury Soup Kitchen is division of the HAVEN (West Berkshire) homeless charity. It is a voluntary organisation providing help and support to the Newbury homeless, rough sleeper community and those less fortunate than others. The primary operation is a friendly drop-in centre for vulnerable adults who perhaps have mental health issues or are just lonely. All are greeted with hot food and drinks every Thursday evening. A warm welcome awaits people who wish to socialise, find support and enjoy a hot meal.

Title: JDRF Bees Country Kitchen Hamper Raffle

Description:
Support Children at Risk of Food Insecurity!

We are master‚Äôs students from the School of Management at the University of Bath raising awareness of food insecurity and funds to combat this issue. Households that are ‚Äòfood insecure‚Äô mean that they cannot guarantee sufficient quality or quantity of food.

Our efforts will be directed to support Kitchen Social, a leading holiday food provision programme in this space.

Founded by an independent charity, the Mayor‚Äôs Fund for London, Kitchen Social gives children and young people a safe place to socialise, learn and get a free, healthy meal. The programme helps to alleviate the financial strain on families that comes with accessing food and childcare activities during the school holidays. Long school breaks, without the support that young people need to thrive, is one of the drivers of educational attainment gaps between young people from different socio-economic backgrounds. Food insecurity over the school holidays can lead to learning loss, lower self-esteem, and weight gain. Poor nutrition and social isolation not only affect a child‚Äôs wellbeing but also impacts physical and mental development, thereby perpetuating the cycle of poverty.

Kitchen Social has a city-wide network of over 100 local community organisations including schools, adventure playgrounds, and youth clubs that provide nutritious food and fun activities. In response to the pandemic, Kitchen Social also created "Take and Make" ‚Äì a recipe box series designed to engage children at home with their families. These boxes contain ingredients for four portions of nutritious food, alongside recipe cards and online video tutorials.


What we'll deliver:

 „ÉªRaise funds for Kitchen Social‚Äôs Take and Make boxes so they can be distributed to young people during the Christmas break, providing opportunities for children to learn new skills and cook together with their parents

„ÉªContribute to Kitchen Social‚Äôs Christmas Grant Activities where families can attend a Christmas party in their local area, access food, and take part in entertaining activities


Why it's a great idea:

Covid-19 has caused the number of families living in food insecurity to rise. A recent Mayor‚Äôs Fund for London survey revealed that 75% of families reported having less money for food. Many do not qualify for government support.

Kitchen Social is stepping up to support more local community organisations during school holidays. Take and Make boxes help to ease the pressure that some parents feel outside of term-time. It is a fantastic way to support a child's wellbeing and encourage young people into the kitchen to learn about ingredients, try new skills and cook nutritious food with families and friends.

We will be running an online cooking class to fundraise for this project. Engaging with two nutrition-based TikTokers and a chef who will be doing a live cook along. These activities aim to:

„ÉªContribute towards Christmas holiday funding, providing young people with activities, social engagement, and a delicious meal during the Christmas break

„ÉªFund ingredients for Take and Make boxes

„ÉªProvide children at risk of food insecurity with Take and Make boxes

More information about our online cooking class is available at the link below!!!:

https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/online-cooking-class-with-nigel-thompson-teawithmrt-tickets-165170827391?keep_tld=1

Description:
The UCKG HelpCentre is a UK charity dedicated to helping people live life to the full ‚Äì physically, emotionally and spiritually. Over the years, we‚Äôve reached such a large and diverse group of individuals that our growing family now includes some 12 million people from all walks of life, across 172 countries.We are highly adaptive, with a close ear to the ground and ready in identifying the needs of people, simply because helping them is what drives us!

5 Alive comprises of 5 different areas we want your help in order to help others 




1.Night Angels

Where a group of volunteers give food to the homeless at night.




2.Give warmth Appeal

Giving warmth to the homeless and less fortunate, especially during winter times.




3. Soup kitchen

Every Saturday from 11am-1pm we are feeding people in our community which amounts to 30,000 people yearly 




4. 24 Hour Helpline

Volunteer advisors are available to speak with and give support to those who are desperate. Especially during times like this with the effect the pandemic is having on people‚Äôs mental health.




5.Food bank 

Helping more than 7,000 families per year within our community with your sponsorship to the UCKG Helpcentre Charity we plan to open 15 more Food Banks which will enable us to reach more than double the amount of people each year 

But we want to do more and you can be apart of it too !

Description: From 12th November 2018, the Newbury Soup Kitchen is division of the HAVEN (West Berkshire) homeless charity. It is a voluntary organisation providing help and support to the Newbury homeless, rough sleeper community and those less fortunate than others. The primary operation is a friendly drop-in centre for vulnerable adults who perhaps have mental health issues or are just lonely. All are greeted with hot food and drinks every Thursday evening. A warm welcome awaits people who wish to socialise, find support and enjoy a hot meal.

Description:
To my wonderful donators! Can you donate ¬£2 for every km that I run ? Will you be my 2020 challenge (20 people donating ¬£20)? Great!! Get donating :) Feel free to donate whatever you can -every little help!  Check out the media gallery to see what your ¬£20 will go towards. Thank you so much!

As part of the UCKG HelpCentre's response to Covid-19,we‚Äôd like to tell you about an exciting new initiative called 5Alive! We have worked and are continuing to work hard to deliver fi ve major community projects this year, with the aim of keeping various members of our community alive throughout this difficult time.
We currently operate a 24-hour helpline, run weekly soup kitchens in five different locations that have fed over 2,000 people throughout the pandemic, as well as food banks in several of our centres across the country. The initiative also includes two other projects: ‚ÄúNight Angels‚Äù, which sees our volunteers take to the streets during the night to provide basic necessities and food packs to those still sleeping rough; and also the Give Warmth Appeal, which extends aid not only to the homeless and those sleeping rough, but to children in hospitals, the children of prison inmates, and others, through gift-giving and the provision of items that will help those struggling get through the cold winter months.

Description:
This is our story..

We are a group of young people taking part in NCS's Summer Scheme. Part of our social action, is to pick a charity and raise awareness, funding and get our hands dirty by giving back to our community.

We have chosen Southport Soup Kitchen as we find their work so important within our local community.

We are hoping to raise money, raise awareness and collecting the essentials like shampoo/sanitary products/soap/food/water/gloves/socks and other things that will make life a little easier for the homeless and people struggling, in and around Southport. 

Any donations are encouraged, we are grateful for every single penny and we hope that you will encourage your family and friends to help us reach our fundraising goal. 

(If you'd like to give us tinned good and long lasting foods, you can drop them off at Southport Community Church Southbank Road, and label the bag with 'Catch 22, Southport group 4' and it will be added to our collection. 

Thank you for your time.

Title: Soup  kitchen helping those in need

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
Many of you have called, emailed or messaged to ask about how we are coping with COVID-19 and the impact it has had on our organisation. Firstly, let me say thank you for the outpouring of support we've received. It's always a heart-warming feeling to know that we have so many incredible supporters. 

Last week, in light of the Coronavirus, we made the difficult decision to offer a takeaway-only food service to guests rather than their usual sit-down meal. As most of you know, we take a huge amount of pride in the fact that we offer not just a warm meal to our guests, but also a safe and warm space off the streets for them for the hours they're with us. As we considered the health risks we decided that it would be prudent to only offer a takeaway food service for the foreseeable future.

Absolutely any donation will have a huge impact on our services. Thank you for helping us support the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate in London!

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
At Tonic, we launched the Pay It Forward campaign as a direct response to October 2020‚Äôs parliamentary vote which denied food to children in need, during the school holidays.

It felt like such a juxtaposition to the abundant hospitality scene we know, to think of these children, hungry through no fault of their own, and we simply had to do something about it.

The Tonic Pay It Forward campaign is simple: for every single complimentary meal we receive or arrange, we donate a meal for someone hungry. And we pledge that it will remain an integral part of this business for as long as we are running. We have huge ambitions for this - we want to raise as much money as possible and connect the disparate food experiences in London and beyond.

So far, together with our community, we have raised over ¬£6,000 including ¬£1,283 for Magic Breakfast, ¬£2,675 for The Trussell Trust, ¬£1,740 for Made in Hackney and over ¬£1,500 for Carib Eats - and this is just the beginning!

Now, as of 19 July 2021, we are fundraising for The Soup Kitchen to help support them in their mission to provide crucial support to homeless and vulnerable people throughout London. Not only do The Soup Kitchen supply healthy and nutritious food, but provide critical mental health support, clothing, and friendship for the homeless, elderly, lonely and vulnerable.

Such is the power of our community, and the calibre of people and companies we partner with, that alongside our donations many clients, journalists and friends have been energised by the initiative and joined us too. There are too many to thank personally, but to all of you committed to creating positive change with us, you are wonderful.
Title: Tonic's Pay It Forward campaign for Soup Kitchen

Description:
This Boxing Day, Chris, Barny and Cathy will be hitting the streets of Central London with a makeshift soup kitchen in the back of 'The Bongo', to give out hot soup, Christmas snacks, doggy treats and blankets to the homeless.

On Boxing Day we'll be mobile around central London in the morning and then pitching up near Trafalgar Square, if you wish to support us on the day please come along with your warm heart and whatever wish you wish to donate.

We've had lots of generous donations from friends already, including soup, blankets, dog food, sleeping bags and serving equipment. Thanks so much to everyone who's helped us so far!

For those of our friends who are simply too far away and would like to help please donate what you can to Crisis.

And for those only able to support in spirit, we would be grateful if you can share our plight with your friends to help raise awareness of the homeless crisis this Christmas.

Thanks so much,

Chris, Barny & Cathy

Title: Boxing Day Bongo - A Mobile Soup Kitchen #xmaspresent

Description:
The last few months have seen immense suffering and hardship from storms and flooding. However the outbreak of the Coronavirus has quite literally changed everyones lives and turned society upside down.
However, The Salvation Army is resolute and strong and just as we did in the Spanish Flu pandemic, and during the bombing and the Blitz we will carry on, doing what we can to support people and communities  in the ways that we can, within the Government guidelines.
In true Salvation Army Spirit, our greatest strength is our flexible, responsive local presence. Right now, each of our 650 corps and community centres will know exactly what the most effective things are to do. We are not just responding to the virus impact in one or two ways, but dozens and dozens of different ways, from food banks to counselling, from supporting NHS isolation units to checking up on people who are living alone
Please give what you can to enable us to help as many people as possible!

Title: Stone Soup Academy

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On the 30th of May 2021 I will be doing another soup challenge! I‚Äôm so committed to finding a CURE for DIPG that I shall be doing this EVERY YEAR on what would of been Kyles birthday! I hope I‚Äôm not still doing it when I‚Äôm 90! There has been no change to the treatment for DIPG since astronaut Neils Armstrong daughter died aged 4 almost 50yrs ago . These children are told to go make some memories. The only treatment they‚Äôre offered is radiotherapy and given some steroids. Their life spans range  from 3 months to 12months . 

Kyle Morrison will be forever 9 , he should have been following his dreams . Kyle wanted to be a police officer. Sadly Kyle left a huge hole in the hearts of his mum Victoria , little brother Tyler and grandmother and all who knew him . DIPG is a monster , it affects their ability to walk , to see , to eat and eventually breathe . It‚Äôs leaves a child trapped in their body in darkness fully aware and in agony. There is no treatment for DIPG, just radiotherapy and steroids. Families are told to make memories. Kyle never got to make memories because the world went into lockdown. Trials all over the world , where also put on hold , so the scientists could find a cure for Covid. We need a cure .

Description:
Thank you for visiting my Kitchen Table Day fundraising page. I'm putting on a Kitchen Table Day to make sure that people with cancer get the support they need. With your generous donations, we can make sure that Maggie's, Edinburgh is there for everyone with cancer and their loved ones. 
I was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer in January 2020. This is a rare breast cancer and can be genetic. The treatment options are fewer and chemo is the  only option. Going through treatment is scary. You fear the worst. Telling your children is difficult. You lose your confidence through losing your hair, putting on weight, lacking energy, feeling helpless. Then after treatment you are left feeling ‚Äòwhat now?‚Äô. Maggie‚Äôs, Edinburgh have been fundamental in supporting my ongoing journey. The support is so needed at this difficult time. I am happy to say I am now cancer free and with the help of Maggie‚Äôs, I‚Äôm staying positive. I have met so many wonderful, inspirational people through Maggie's and I'd like to support them in fundraising.
Please come along for a tea/coffee and sample some lovely home baking. I look forward to seeing you there. Thank you :O)
Title: Ruth's page - Raising funds for Maggie's Centre, Edinburgh

Description: Thank you visiting my Kitchen Table Day fundraising page. I'm putting on a Kitchen Table Day to make sure that people with cancer get the support they need. With your generous donations, we can make sure that Maggie's is there for everyone with cancer and their loved ones. Thank you.

Description:
Action for Pulmonary Fibrosis (APF) is a growing community of patients, families, researchers and healthcare professionals striving to find a cure for pulmonary fibrosis so that everyone affected by the disease has a better future. We provide personalised support to patient and families - and raise awareness of pulmonary fibrosis through campaigning, fundraising and education. We are also committed to funding research to improve the quality of life for people living with pulmonary fibrosis today and tomorrow.

Pook's story is available on my website : www.thetruthaboutipf.  

He fought a brave and far too short battle against this disease.
Title: Pook Zanetti's Birthday

Description: Annabel is 8 years old and has a big heart for helping others. She came to me when she was about 3 or 4 years old, upset that boys and girls were getting sick because they didn't have what she took for granted. Since then she has sent some pocket money but wants to do more. The soup and sweet lunch is her idea and she is organising it. She truly believes that clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone‚Äôs daily life. Without all three, people can‚Äôt live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.
Title: Annabel's Soup and Sweet Lunch

Description: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation's research and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. ¬£24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

Title: Zena's One Soup On A Sunday

Description:
In February 2021 I was diagnosed with Stage 3 Ovarian cancer. Everything has not always gone to plan, my op was longer, my chemotherapy involved stays in hospital and my current treatment needed tweaks. The knowledge within the Marsden made it all, almost seamless, and I am but one patient. People from all over the world benefit from their expertise.

After raising ¬£2250 for Macmillan, this is now my way of thanking the Marsden for their care of me and all the other patients, both now and in the future. My current oral chemotherapy will last for another two years and thereafter I will have checks - I have no urgent end date of my fundraising so as I am often asked to do demonstrations, lessons and talks, sometimes instead of a fee, I will direct them to here. I will also run specific fundraisers. It makes me feel really good doing this and any amount of donation is great, I just feel incredibly fortunate to be able to use my skills to raise money.

So where will the money go?

 Well, The Royal Marsden are known world-wide as a world-leading cancer centre and The Royal Marsden Cancer Charity raises money solely to support The Royal Marsden.  They ensure nurses, doctors and research teams provide the very best care and develop life-saving treatments, used across the UK and around the world. Pioneering research is absolutely critical to extending, improving and saving the lives of more people diagnosed with cancer. From funding state-of-the-art equipment and ground-breaking research, to creating the very best patient environments, they will never stop looking for ways to improve the lives of people affected by cancer. 

Thank you for your support,

Love Ruth










.

Description:
It's been a tough year this year for everyone but it's been even worse for amazing charities like Macmillan Cancer Support. They rely heavily on events like fun runs and bake sales to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support.

That 'Virus' will be gone soon enough but sadly Cancer will continue to touch all of our lives at some point for the foreseeable future.

We'd love our wonderful viewers / listeners to just donate a round of drinks or if you're keeping it simply maybe just that couple of pounds you were going to spend on that pint you were going to treat yourself tonight. Just think of all that good your simple donation could do!

Come on, you know it makes sense!

Description:
Homeless Project Scotland is a Homeless Charity in Scotland founded in October 2019. We achieved charitable status in June 2020. We are a non-profit organization operated by a Board of Trustees in order to help the homeless and vulnerable in Scotland. 

Our purpose is to feed and provide support to homeless and vulnerable people. We also act as a trusted voice for the homeless and It is vital that we have integrity. We aim to be effective, efficient, independent and trustworthy. Our approach is to listen, learn, act and then speak.

Description:
The Curry Kitchen
The Curry Kitchen is a pioneering partnership project with Community Interest Luton, Venue Central, Discover Islam Information Centre and local businesses. Our aim is to provide hot meals to the most needy in Luton once a week.


We run a weekly Curry Kitchen service as well as delivering food prepared to homeless shelters in the locality. The project is sponsored by the local business community.

Furthermore, volunteers from various local businesses are on the frontline working together to provide hot meals to the homeless and most vulnerable.

Title: Cameron Kitchen

Description:
For the next four weeks we'll be without a clean and decent kitchen as we're having it rebuilt. Already we've lost the use of the washing machine and - oh my gods - even the dishwasher! How will we ever cope?

However, we are fully aware that we're very lucky to have a waterproof roof over our heads, heat, light, hot and cold running water, food, wine, gin & tonic, and all the other essentials and luxuries we take for granted in our first world, middle class, and comfortably funded lives.

We know this is not the case for everyone, so in the spirit of "giving something up for charity", we'd love it if you could see your way clear to donating any spare funds you may have to homelessness charity Crisis, via this page. Think of it as if we'd given up alcohol or chocolate for a month. Think, also, of all the lovely food our new kitchen will be able to produce and to which you may well be invited in the future.

Please give generously if you can.

NB. We will be donating too!

Thank you!

Antony & Liz
Title: Antony & Liz's kitchen rebuild

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Ramadan is the most wonderful time of the year, full of countless reward, blessings, mercy, togetherness and forgivenesss. It is the perfect time for us to come together, give thanks to Allah (swt), and give to those in need.Many of us are fortunate enough to have a cooked meal during suhoor and iftari, however, this is not the case for the thousands living in war-torn areas. 

With your help we can help raise money to provide cooked meals to 500 people in Lebanon/Yemen/Gaza. These people have little or no means of providing for themselves, and during this month of Ramadan we should uphold our values and think of those less fortunate than ourselves. 

All donations will be sent to the Al-khair foundation, so that they are able to use this money to provide families and children with meals. 

And they give food, out of love for Him, to the poor and the orphan and the captive, [saying] ‚ÄúWe feed you, for Allah's pleasure only ‚Äî We desire from you neither reward nor thanks. Surely we fear from our Lord a stern, distressful day.‚Äù

Many thanks for your support. 

Let‚Äôs make a difference starting today.

Description:
The Wildheart Trust is based at the Isle of Wight Zoo on the east coast of the island. It's most treasured aim is to give safe and loving forever homes to big cats and other exotic animals which have been abused in circuses and in the pet trade. 

The Wildheart Trust has recently provided a forever home for five tigers from their former circus life and, more recently, two ex-circus lions but they don't want to stop there! The Trust is now keen to look into the rescue of bile bears from Asia, and Barbery macaques from North Africa. Animals that never have, nor ever will be able to live in the wild.

They cannot do this alone and need help and assistance from like-minded individuals to assist in their rescue and rehabilitation work!

Description:

We are highly adaptive, with a close ear to the ground and ready in identifying the needs of people, simply because helping them is what drives us!

Title: Soph's page

Description:
Last year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. It‚Äôs not right that people can‚Äôt afford the basics. With your help, we can help end the need for food banks.As a nation, we expect no one should be left hungry or destitute. Illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job can happen to any of us. With your help #ThisCanChange

Soup kitchens need even more support right now as we go into winter during this challenging time. Everyone deserves food security and Id like to do my little bit. Classes are open to all, I will be running them on different days and times so as many people as possible can access them.

Mindfulness is a skill which has helped me a lot in my life and I cant wait to pass this skill onto more people. Taking care of mental health has never been so important.
Title: Cheryl's online mindfulness classes for Trussell Trust

Description:
The UCKG HelpCentre is a UK charity dedicated to helping people live life to the full ‚Äì physically, emotionally and spiritually. The 5Alive appeal comprises of 5 different ways that you can help us to make a difference in our local communities:

1. Night Angels - With your help we can provide food packs and basic necessities for the homeless and rough sleepers in our communities

2. Give Warmth - With this initiative we can provide warm items of clothing for the homeless and less fortunate this winter

3. Soup Kitchen - We run a soup kitchen every Saturday in various branches across London. We have been able to feed 30,000 people since beginning and with your help, we can reach more people

4. 24/7 Helpline - We run a 24/7 helpline to support and advice those who are vulnerable and in need emotional support

5. Food Bank - Our Food Bank has been helping more than 7,000 families per year within our community and will be especially vital during this COVID-19 pandemic

Thank you in advance for your support. It is without a doubt greatly appreciated.
Title: Eniola 5Alive Fundraiser!

Description:
The Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (UCKG) is a Christian Ministry and registered charity (1043985) dedicated to helping people live life to the fullest ‚Äî physically, emotionally and spiritually.Over the years, we have reached such a diverse group of people that our work has touched millions across over 170 countries. Their unique stories remind us that with the right kind of help and support, the most heartbreaking stories can become tomorrow‚Äôs inspirational ones. In these testing times, we are determined to do more. Support us


This year we have 5 community outreach projects dedicated to helping people in need.

1. Soup kitchen at various locations across london every saturday to give warm soup and light refreshments to homeless people. 

2. Night Angel's which takes place every Friday night where we go into the streets of london to give homeless people a bag which has blankets, hats, gloves, food and hygiene products.

3. Give warmth appeal of which we visit the elderly in nursing homes and children in hospital to give gifts and spend time with them.

4. Food bank in which bags of groceries are given ti families in need of some extra support in these holidays.

5. 24 hour helpline which is available for those who need encouragement, an ear to talk to and advise at any time if the day or night.

Description:
I met the SEAPIA staff two years ago and fell in love with their passion for childcare and the enthusiasm for the community they live and work in. 

SEAPIA has been part of the Fulham community for 48 years. They provide a safe and fun place for the Sand's End children to play and learn. They regularly put on events that the entire community can attend. 

After 10 years, their kitchen has run it's course and needs to be replaced. The kitchen is regularly used to prepare snacks and is a viable asset when hiring the hall for fundraising purposes. 

A new kitchen would enable staff to run cooking classes, make better use of the space and increase people's interest to hire the hall.
Title: New Kitchen for SEAPIA

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My brother Mark Kitchener suffered from kidney disease and then kidney failure 20 years ago. 18 years ago St Helier hospital and the renal unit saved him from all of the terrible sessions of dialysis by performing a kidney transplant. The transplanted kidney was given a life of 10 years but it actually lasted 18 years. Unfortunately Mark had a stroke in September and although he was starting to recover it was not to be and he sadly passed away on 18th November 2017. Mark always supported the South West Thames Kidney Fund as they are working towards a cure for kidney disease.

Description:
On the 11th of March, I got  a phone call from my step Mum, telling me Dad had died from a heart attack. 

Dad did have a heart condition, but the Doctor's said they hadn't seen anyone as active as he was. He loved to cycle, and we often cycled together. Dad showed no signs of struggling near the end, he seemed fine. We were all taken by surprise. In memory of him, I will cycle 100km and raise money for the BHF. So that - one day - no other families will have to suffer the tragedy of an unexpected loss due to heart disease. 

The ride will take place on the 1st of August.

Description:
Rob Kitchen (1964-2018)

Rob Kitchen was a likable character with an endearing personality who began working with the finance team at Salford City Council in September 2005.  He initially came across as a quiet and private individual, but once you got to know him you found that he had many varying interests from rock music to history.  In particular Rob had a passion for the arts and was a frequent patron of ‚ÄòHome‚Äô, formerly ‚ÄòThe Corner House‚Äô.

Rob commenced 2018 like any other year and was present in work during the month of January. Unfortunately though, he became ill very quickly and sadly passed away in March 2018, aged only 53.

Rob received excellent care in Christies for the last month of his life and as a result we, ‚ÄòRob‚Äôs Runners‚Äô,  are going to run/jog/walk the Salford 10k on Sunday 9th September 2018 in his memory.

If you would like to join Rob‚Äôs Runners please email kieran.mcelwee@salford.gov.uk or
mags.miller-cobham@salford.gov.uk for further details.

Title: Remembering Anna

Description:
This year I am fundraising for The People's Kitchen, a charity located in Newcastle that provides meals for the homeless and disadvantaged individuals.

I want to support this cause because every time I stroll through the streets of Newcastle, I am always stunned to see a large number of rough sleepers that are wondering if tonight they will be fortunate enough to eat or find a one-night placement at a shelter.

I realise how lucky I am to have a roof over my head, a fridge full of food, and clothes on my back. I have a boiler that kicks in when I am cold; these poor souls only have the streets.

So, my mission is quite a simple one, this year I want to fundraise at least ¬£100 (To buy 100 dinners for people who need them).

I will donate ¬£20 that I have saved in fuel since the university moved to online sessions. Please give what you can if you would like to contribute towards this great cause.

Title: Jennifer's Kitchen Nightmares

Description:
On Saturday 9th May, we lost our beloved Dad, husband, Grandad and great-Grandad. He had fought hard for months but in the end, his leukemia and Covid took him from us. He will be forever in our hearts.

Typical of Dad, he did not want any fuss at the end. He simply just wanted to go. To respect his wishes, we would like to ask for donations instead of flowers. Dad was a huge animal lover and especially in the last few weeks, he got an enormous amount of joy just sitting in the garden with his dogs. Therefore, it seems fitting to support his local animal rescue home. We are sure this would make him happy!

Please feel free to donate if you would like to and to leave a message or memory of Eddie.

Dads cremation is taking place on Tuesday 26th May. Please feel free to raise a glass or two for him.

Thank you for support,

Ann, Quentine and Michaela
Title: In memory of Eddie Kitchen

Assalamu Alaykum,

Suhayb ibn Sinan reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said, ‚ÄúThe best of you are those who feed others.‚Äù

Source: Musnad A·∏•mad 23408 Grade: Sahih (authentic) according to Al-Albani

In these blessed days of Dhul-Hijjah, we are fundraising for The Open Kitchen (run by Muslim Hands). The Open Kitchen is a community kitchen based in West London that provides free meals to anyone in need, seven days a week.

Description:
Instead of wedding presents, we'd love for our guests to donate to the Albert Kennedy Trust (akt), if they feel able to do so.

About akt:

Lots of young people come out as LGBTQ+ to their families and are embraced and supported. But that‚Äôs not always the case. Coming out, or being outed as LGBTQ+ can lead to young people being made homeless. This is the reality for 77% of the young people akt supports. Sometimes families are unaccepting and abusive. The locks changed. Possessions destroyed. akt exists to support these young people and can offer safety and hope in an open and accepting environment. We help with housing and also to help them celebrate their identity.

It's hard to believe that in one of the wealthiest places on earth in 2017 children are returning from their holidays with malnutrition. Anything you can contribute would be massively appreciated by some special kids in the capital.
