Description:
We were meant to hold our cake bake this week, but we‚Äôre not letting working-from-home get in the way of us raising money for a good cause. So step away from your lap-top and get out your food mixer.

When?

Entries must be in by 12 noon on Friday 29 January.

How will it work?

There will be two categories ‚Äì one for children (under 12)
and one for adults.

Just whip up your best baking and send a picture and description into the Aegon AM UK Charity MB. Our cake-loving judges will then decide who is our best baker ‚Äì there is a promise of a (modest) prize ‚Äì but more importantly, you could have the glory of being the winner of the 2021 Virtual Bake-Off.

Our judges will be Anne Scott and Alistair Fruzynski of Nuffield gym.  Many of you have participated in Alistair‚Äôs popular exercise classes, which you can link to from the intranet.  More classes have been included for example, Yoga, Body Tone and exercises you can do at your desk.   Classes are free to all staff. So if you feel you have eaten too much cake, there is plenty of opportunity to burn it off!

Please sponsor your colleagues and donate generously to Cure Parkinson's Trust, our 2021 charity of the year.

About Cure Parkinson's Trust

Founded in 2005 by four people living with the condition, the Cure Parkinson's Trust (CPT) takes a patient-centric approach to funding innovative projects and inspirational scientists, working to modify the progression of Parkinson‚Äôs and to find a cure. At CPT we believe that we are closer than ever to delivering treatments that for the first time will slow, stop or even reverse the progression of the disease. Your donation will help us get there.
Title: Beyond your Kitchen Cupboards - Virtual Cake Bake

Description:
Thank you for visiting our JustGiving page.

We are raising funds for Kitchen Social, part of the Mayor‚Äôs Fund for London, to provide healthy recipe boxes to children during the school
holidays. We want to make a positive difference for children in our local area and we would love your help.  

The pandemic has had a devastating impact on children‚Äôs access to food. In London alone, 400,000 children currently face food insecurity, and right here in our local area of Southwark, increasing numbers of children are eligible for free school meals, leaving them vulnerable to holiday hunger outside of term time, during weekends and holidays. Over the course of this pandemic, Southwark Council estimates the number of children eligible for free school meals has doubled.

These children are in desperate need of our support over the holiday period. 

Last year, Kitchen Social was able to distribute 15,989 Take & Make boxes across our local area, equating to 63,956 meals. Take and Make Boxes are designed to get children to cook healthy food in their homes ‚Äì every box contains high quality, healthy ingredients with step-by-step instructions and video tutorials, providing an educational, familial and dignified solution to holiday hunger.
 

With so much in the news this year about school meals and food insecurity, we reached out to charities working in our local area, and we identified that Kitchen Social was making a tremendous difference right here in Southwark.  

We would be delighted to have your support ‚Äì gifts of any size can provide food for a family that needs our help during the school holidays.  

All donations will go directly to The Mayor‚Äôs Fund for London charity and will be used to provide ‚ÄòTake and Make‚Äô weekend meal boxes for children in Southwark who desperately need them.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
Title: Dulwich College Upper School Charity -  Kitchen Social

Description:
On September 12, I'm running the Great North Run. A year and a half ago I'd never run more than a bath, so getting around the course will be an achievement. So, to recognise this progression from zero to 13.1 miles, please send some money to this amazing charity. 

The People's Kitchen has been helping support homeless and vulnerable people in and around Newcastle since 1984. Throughout the pandemic it has been open, providing hot takeaway meals seven days a week, and giving a vital lifeline to people who might be at risk of homelessness, unemployed, lonely or living in poverty. For people who experience these difficulties, this place is a light in the dark.

I have been privileged to volunteer with the Kitchen since the start of this year. Each Wednesday night is the highlight of my week. The positivity and open-mindedness of the team of volunteers, and the incredible resilience in the face of unfathomable adversity shown by some of our Friends, is truly inspiring. 

By helping this amazing charity you are helping the people in our community who most need our support. In recent weeks we've served upwards of 250 hot meals a night. There's sadly no sign of demand decreasing any any time soon, so anything you can give will make a real difference. 


Thank you! üòä
Title: Fundraising Sprint: Great North Run for the People's Kitchen

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page

Santander and myself are making a joint effort to raise as much as possible to pay for our ‚ÄúFRIENDS‚Äù to have a three course Xmas lunch at ¬£5.00 per person why are we doing this I ask. 

Well the reason is this because we take for granted spending time around a family table  with family enjoying our Christmas lunch when all around us are people sleeping in the streets with no one and hungry.

A lot of my work colleagues spend ¬£3.05 in a Costa coffee shop on a daily basis now how would it feel to give that up for just one day and pay for a three course meal instead, a play on emotions I know but how would that make u feel knowing u spent ¬£5 on a three course meal at Christmas time giving to a stranger knowing they have been fed and watered on ur donation 

I don‚Äôt ask for much but please donate what you can you will feel great and also donate to a worthy cause

What we raise Santander will match also !!!!!

Thank you in advance 

Tracie  and Santander xxx

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On the 5th July 2018 my youngest son Milo was born, he was immediately taken to ICU as he was clearly very poorly. Over the next day he began to show symptoms of a problem which, having been transferred to Brighton was diagnosed as a twisted bowel. My wife was unable to travel and I followed Milo down to Brighton were he was operated on in the early hours.

After 3hrs of surgery, Milo surgeon delivered us the good news that the bowel had been reattached and that no lasting damage had been done. Eventually my wife was able to travel down to Brighton to be reunited with Milo & I could return home to look after our eldest Felix with the hope that all would be fine & within a week or so we would be home.

Unfortunately Milo although growing stronger & getting over the infection he was born with he was unable to eat & so further investigations were needed. After a few weeks & many journeys down to Brighton he was eventually diagnosed with Hirschsprung Disease.

https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hirschsprungs-disease/

Having had a pull through operation at 3 months to remove 10cm of his colon. Milo is now 13 months and doing brilliantly. But challengers lie ahead and a little donation to CHAMPS appeal will raise much need awareness by bringing families with HD children together & supporting families in understanding the diseases and improving awareness of it.

Thanks Freddie, Lizzie, Felix & Milo
Title: Milo's Wild Seasoning Kitchen Asian Inspired Supperclubs

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In February 2020 I had a life enriching  trip to Memusi school in Magadi, Kenya along with other volunteers.The foundation has established three schools over the last 15 yrs supporting over 1000 primary children aged 3-14 from the local Masai community. Many of these children walk for miles to school each day from their villages and the school provides often their only hot meal of the day. The current kitchen was built for 100 children but now they feed 400.

Many of these children live in homes with no electricity or running water including my sponsored son Brian. The teachers I met were inspirational and welcomed all the volunteers with open arms and certainly touched my heart.

When Peter and I both retire next year ,we will return to Memusi as soon as we are allowed and will help with education and healthcare.

It would be wonderful if there could be a new kitchen in place to feed all the children and buy food and goats for the community. Starvation has been a major concern for the foundation over the pandemic.
Title: Gill's Appeal to raise money for a new kitchen and to support Memusi school

Description:
This year, Corpus Christi MCR have pooled together all the second-hand kitchen items at Leck. It is yours for the taking - but we want to use this opportunity to encourage you to donate your small (virtual) change to help support a local cause: the Cambridge Street Aid fund which provides effective support to the homeless of Cambridge.

You can find the stock in the MCR cupboards in the Cricket/Erg Pavilion, out in the Leckhampton playing fields. We ask you to consider making a small donation to the MCR, which we are forwarding on directly to the Cambridge Street Aid fund.

Check out the inventory here before heading down to the Pavilion:‚Ä®https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1XlwkDLYxe3s5IJaYiVKMrgDzJxKvTBGXPSQyqSz9XdI/edit?usp=sharing
(Consider making a note in the spreadsheet when you take an item, so others do not go looking for the same one in vain!)‚Ä®
Title: Corpus MCR Pre-Loved Kitchen fundraiser for Cambridge Street Aid

Description:
Since 2015 something extraordinary has happened when thousands of fellow human beings have come close to home needing help, we have got up and helped and whilst doing that we have unintentionally created a new way of helping that‚Äôs accessible to all.A revolutionary way of helping that provides humanity and nourishment to hungry and vulnerable people creating a connected and kinder world & our mission is to give highly nutritional food support to displaced people whatever their situation. Food is a language the crosses all borders.

In the words of our founder Max.....


"This group was never about trade in the economic sense. It was always about humanity and it was always about love. And it was also about understanding that music is an *essential* element of our being human. We have every reason to think that communities have been singing, playing, drumming and dancing together for hundreds of thousands of years, with every song and beat binding people together, literally creating and perpetuating harmony across our planet.

In our modern world, and contrary to all our instincts, we have commodified our artistic output and although we have created great art, high and low, in the process, we have also forgotten that music belongs to us all. If you have ever felt like expressing yourself artistically but stopped because you felt that your art was not worthy, the Viral Jukebox is your home. I mean it.

More than once since I created this group people have suggested that I could find a way to monetise it. They are missing the point. The currency here is love. Spend freely. Give freely. And remember, if you sang or played it from your heart, you played it right."

So this Christmas, with the Pandemic rolling on and weird hybrid lockdown in place, we thought it would be great to raise money, together, for our favourite causes, so choose the one closest to your heart (or follow the person who made a song you like and vote for a cause they love!)

Happy Christmas Jukeboxers!
Title: Viral Jukebox Christmas Crackers - Christmas Songs for Refugee Kitchen

Description:
After maintaining a number of their UK Outreach services throughout the pandemic, they are ready to rebuild in Northern France and to resume full service throughout the UK. A small COVID-19 response team, including the co-founders, are re-opening the kitchen, assessing the need in the region and slowly, safely and ethically rebuilding our operations accordingly. 

They we need your support as we rebuild!

Please donate and share, so that they can rebuild our stores of essentials such as rice, spices, gloves, Vegware, beans, oil, fresh veg, fuel and much more!

¬£10 = 12 litres of cooking oil

¬£20 = 75 tins of tomatoes

¬£50 = 55kg Basmati rice

¬£100 = 85kg dried beans

RCK is 100% dependent on donations, they really need your support in this crucial time. Please help us get back on their feet so that we can continue our mission of serving nutritious food without judgement.

Description:
There is a circulatory post going around social media where someone posts that they dress up as a unicorn and dance around their kitchen. Then anyone who reacts to that post is sent a message telling them that they fell for it and that the idea is to spread awareness about breast cancer. They are then instructed to post the same thing on their wall in order to keep it spreading. 

This was great for spreading awareness but I saw no link to any benefit to sufferers or charities. So I've decided to do what the post says. I will dress up as a unicorn, cover myself in glitter and dance around my kitchen for you...but only if we can raise some actual funds to support those suffering from the disease. 

So if you want me to make an embarrassment of myself and give some cash to a good cause please donate!

Description:
The Curry Kitchen is a pioneering partnership project between Community Interest Luton and Discover Islam Information Centre and local businesses.

Each hot and nutritious meal costs just ¬£1.80 per person and every penny of your donation goes towards providing the meal. So you know that everything you give will help feed someone in need.

We have provided over 26,000 hot meals since we started, which is truly amazing! But we need to make sure we can keep feeding those people most in need each week and have to raise around ¬£9,360 to provide enough meals for one year.

COVID has had a huge impact on this project. Firstly, the need and demand for hot food has gone up significantly and this will only get worse as the nights get longer, it gets colder and the weather gets worse.

A donation of ¬£18 will help feed ten people and provide them with a safe and warm space to eat, talk to others and access the additional support they need. Anything you can donate to help the homeless and vulnerable people from across the town, would be directly helping to relieve hunger and loneliness in Luton.

Description:
Every year since 2004, the North Wales link of the Chernobyl Children‚Äôs Lifeline Charity has been bringing children from Belarus & the Ukraine over to North Wales for a one month health respite visit. These children & their families are still suffering the devastating effects of the Chernobyl disaster, over 30 years later.  The conditions these families live in is heartbreaking.  Most families do not have the basic facilities that we take for granted such as running water in our homes & indoor toilets. 

The children are born with such low immune systems they often suffer from ill health, with many developing cancer.  Just four weeks staying with host families can help to prolong their lives by up to 4 years!

For those 4 weeks the children stay with host families, with the charity organising fun days out and activities during the week where they get to just enjoy being children & meeting the people who so generously donate clothes, gifts & supplies. They are taken to the dentist, the opticians & are supplied with immune boosting vitamins during their visit.  We also collect medical supplies such as paracetamol, sudocrem, plasters, antiseptic creams etc to take home to the families.

Bringing these children over every year is only part of what the link is all about. We are constantly fundraising so we can support the families back home in Belarus & the Ukraine. We have just successfully raised enough money to provide a toilet block for the village school, next on the agenda is providing them with a school kitchen & dining area as what they currently use is indescribable. 

Thank you for taking the time to read this & if you are able to donate thank you so much!! Keep an eye out for updates & if you‚Äôd like to get in touch or see what the children have been up to follow our facebook page. 

https://en-gb.facebook.com/NorthWalesCCLL/

Description:
What is Emmies Kitchen? Emmies kitchen was set up after my great niece was diagnosed with leukaemia and had to spend lots of time in RMCH. It became obvious quite quickly that the availability of home made tasty food is extremely limited whilst staying at hospital. Emmies kitchen provides parents of children staying in the hospital with a free, cooked tasty take away meals and a snack bag, During Covid they have offered this once a week to long term parents at the hospital. It is apparent that looking after the well being of parents is vital for their child's recovery. 

With my friend Pete we aim to walk the 84 miles of Hadrian's Wall from Bowness-on-Solway to Wallsend in Newcastle. We will be camping on route and carrying all our own equipment (no Sherpas will be involved) Support us on our journey by giving a donation to Emmies Kitchen.
Title: Hadrian's Wall walk challenge for Emmies Kitchen Friday Night Take Away

Rum Shack Live At Union Chapel is donating 20% of ticket sales to our friends at Refugee Community Kitchen

Rum Shack was founded by Steve Bedlam, who went on to co-found Refugee Community Kitchen. RCK are close to our hearts at The Common Glastonbury (our field) and we have witnessed their remarkable and tireless work first hand. Please help us support them.

After maintaining a number of their UK Outreach services throughout the pandemic, they are ready to rebuild in Northern France and to resume full service throughout the UK. A small COVID-19 response team, including the co-founders, are re-opening the kitchen, assessing the need in the region and slowly, safely and ethically rebuilding our operations accordingly. 

They need your support as they rebuild!

Description:
Alzheimer‚Äôs Society is transforming the landscape of dementia forever. Until the day a cure is found,  they create a society where those affected by dementia are supported and accepted, able to live in their community without fear or prejudice. 

At Margaret‚Äôs Cottage and Mrs. C‚Äôs Home Kitchen, we have put our creative, culinary heads together to raise some much-needed cash for the Alzheimer‚Äôs Society.

Alzheimer‚Äôs disease is the most common form of dementia and it touches so many families, including our own. We want to support the Alzheimer‚Äôs Society because it funds research into the cause, cure, care and prevention of dementia. Alzheimer‚Äôs and other forms of dementia do not just involve memory loss. Dementia is a terminal
disease of the brain that affects difficulties with thinking, problem-solving, confidence, ability and language.

We [Sharon and Ciara] will spend days donating our time,  our energy and  our skills into producing some of your favourite delicious treats, so you can pre-order and then purchase and collect your items on Saturday 22nd of May at the Alzheimer's [virtual] Bake Sale.

We'd love you to donate , if you cannot support our Bake Sale.

Or donate AND order some of our cakes. Your donation might even off-set your calories! Well, it's worth a try.

Description:
Hi everyone,

I know it hasn't been long but me and a few mates are doing another 24 hour stream. This time, I have set up a Just Giving page to help the NHS fight the Coronavirus.

Not only am I raising money for the NHS fighting COVID-19 but I am raising money for them to help my Grandad (David Kitchener) who has unfortunately contracted the virus last week. With great sadness he passed away on the 6th of may midday. He was an amazing man and my best friend. 

If you know me then you know that I am very close to my Grandad and have travelled all over the country with him when he has taken me to my athletics meetings. He has supported me through thick and thin and now it is time to support him in his hour of need. If it wasn't for my Grandad I wouldn't be the man that I am today as he helped shape me and pushed me to be the best that I can through sport and his endless love for his family. My Nan (Jane Kitchener) is at home alone now and it seems unfair but this is how things are now. She is surrounded by people who love her and the support that we have had from the people around us is amazing.

My grandad was an amazing man and will be so proud and grateful for all your donations. The NHS did everything they could to help him however after fighting for 6 long and hard weeks his body could no longer take it due to one thing or another. 

The NHS have been doing a Fantastic Job all over the country and they need our support to fight this virus. From the Doctors and Nurses to the reception staff they have all had a hand in helping loved ones get back on their feet, no matter the challenge.

Please donate to this fantastic cause and help the people we love return to the people that they love.

We will start streaming at 1800hrs on Sunday the 10th of may through to the 11th of may at 1800hrs.

I will be streaming over on twitch so please feel free to drop by. Link will be in the comments to my channel.

Please share this amazing story of Lord Kitch and the NHS Fighting off COVID-19
Title: 24hr stream for the NHS and Lord Kitch fighting Covid 19

Description:
( Everyone Please leave your e mail Address so that I can send you a personal thank you for donating)

‚Ä¶no matter how big government gets, and no matter how many services it provides, it can never take the place of volunteers.
- Ronald Reagan, 40th U.S. president

PENNINES IN PYJAMAS,

Yes never been done before, I will walk the whole route wearing me Pyjamas and carry an Ironing Board to attract as much Sponsorship along the route as possible. I'm 'Mad' about raising money for the Rifles, please help me raise the funds the Soldiers and their Families deserve.

"Superhuman effort isn't worth a damn unless it achieves results Ernest Shackleton


'To live in the Hearts we leave behind is not to Die'

" Pray for the dead And fight like hell for the living ! "

While serving I won Exercise Yorkshire Canter twice in the eighties, covering 100 miles in 24hrs, carrying full kit and Rifle, changed my socks after the first 60 miles whether they needed it or not, when you do something such as this you just keep your body moving, there's plenty of time to rest at the finish point. I Completed an 85 km X Country Ski marathon in 7hrs 01 min and even managed to run the Basic Fitness Test of 1 1/2 mile backwards in under 11 & 1/2 mins.

On the 7th August 2010 I walked unaided/unsupported and at nil costs the whole length of Hadrians Wall 84 miles, carrying a Kitchen Sink on my back, donated and sponsored by B&Q in Stockton -on-Tees.

The response I got from everyone was amazing and quite simply the tourists I met along the way could not believe it and the donations I received showed their respect for the Soldiers in the Rifles Regiment. (Nearly ¬£500), all that brass made my rucksack even heavier !

I have now received nearly ¬£4000 and this does not include the gift aid, the money will be used well and greatly appreciated by the Soldiers and their families, once again many thanks.

I am coming out of retirement again ! to complete this challenge because I want to "do" something to Support 'The Rifles Charities- Care for Casualties

I said to my Wife that I quite fancied a couple of days by the Seaside for Easter, one day at St Bee's the other at Robin Hood's bay she said that's nice, only trouble is I will have to walk the 192 miles in between!!!

I am going to be dropped off for free at St Bee's by my mate who lives at Robin Hood's bay I will then buy a local postcard put a 2nd class stamp on it to give me a fighting chance and Address it to my mate then look out Royal Mail as I attempt to race your snail mail back to Robin Hood's bay!!!

I will walk, run stroll or trot it don't matter a jot as long as I get from West to East with my Ironing Board on my back and collect donations along the way, I will be seen by many flying the Rifles Flag and standing in places like Kirby Stephen I will ensure that everyone is made aware of the Care for Casualties Charity.

''Never mourn a man's death in combat, but thank God for making such a man'. Father, Christopher Green.

"You will find, as you look back upon your life, that the moments that stand out are the moments when you have done things for others."
Henry Drummond

" We make a living by what we get,

but we make a life by what we give "

Sir Winston Churchill

 

Remember, if you ever need a helping hand, you'll find one at the end of your arm ... As you grow older you will discover that you have two hands. One for helping yourself, the other for helping others. Audrey Hepburn

There's always free cheese in the mouse traps, but the mice there ain't happy.
- Anonymous

I work for Linden Lodge Neuro-rehabilitation Unit at Nottingham City Hospital. We care for and provide rehabilitation to patients that have complex brain and spinal injuries as well as those with long term disabilities such as multiple sclerosis (MS). We are trying to raise funds to upgrade the patient kitchen area. 

This is used for therapeutic sessions as well as encouraging independence for those patients that are able to make their own food and drinks.

The plan is to have new units, cooker and equipment. Even better would be able to have enough to have a "floating" work surface that will allow all patients, whether wheelchair bound or standing, to be able to utilise the space. We know that it is going to be expensive - in the region of around ¬£15,000 and that this will only be a small step towards it.

I am hoping to raise at least ¬£500 for a complete head shave - please be generous!
Title: Helen's brave the Shave for Linden Lodge

Description: Julian House helps the most marginalised people in society to regain their self-confidence and take back control of their lives. From living on the streets, to seeking employment, Julian House services give life changing, and often life saving support.
Title: liam's Cake sale

Description:
This week we received news of a devastating storm at the Special School at Mvomero!  Luckily everyone is safe, but the damage is extensive.

The Special School for the Deaf at Mvomero has been working really hard to establish itself as a government primary school. The staff go the extra mile to support these children with hearing impairment helping them succeed at primary level. The work they do is important...

This unusually violent storm hit the School, destroying the kitchen, the water tanks, the cowsheds, chicken-house, and much more... 

The priority now is to secure a water supply, get the kitchen up and running again (this provides meals for 40 children and staff), as well as providing protection for the animals (these provide food for the community as well as an income). The heavy rains are due at the beginning of February so we need to make significant progress in making repairs very quickly.
Title: Amani Special School's Emergency Appeal

Description:
Being in lockdown and spending more time in my hood made me appreciate our local community more than ever. My neighbour Kie-My sent details of a group of locals coming together to do a Triathlon at Blenheim Palace to get fit and raise money for local charities. And I thought....you know what...I'm in!

With over 200 in the team now and loads of organised fitness events over the past number of months it's been a great experience so far.....now just need to do the actual thing!

I'm supporting Kie-My and the amazing work she does with 9 Kitchens and Salusbury World to empower women of migrant status. You can read more about the project here... https://www.bompureasianfood.com/9kitchens-womenrefugees

...and if you can donate a couple of quid then you're an awesome human and it would be received with gratitude

Description:
PAPYRUS is the national Charity for the Prevention of Young Suicide. Suicide is the biggest killer of young people under the age of 35 in the UK, in 2018 over 1800 young people took their own lives. PAPYRUS provides confidential support and advice to young people struggling with thoughts of suicide, and anyone worried about a young person through their helpline, HOPELINEUK. Every ¬£5 raised can help pay for a life-saving contact to HOPELINEUK. Your donations really are lifesaving, thank you.

Swansea University is proud to support PAPYRUS and the invaluable work it does with young people in our community. HOPEWALKS take place across the UK throughout October to get the conversation started around suicide. We want Swansea's HOPEWALK to raise awareness, raise money and reduce stigma. 

Please join us on our 3 mile circular beach walk  - just remember to wear suitable footwear and dress sensibly!

Event sponsored by The Secret Beach Bar and Kitchen, Mumbles Road, Swansea

Sunday 31st October @ 10:30am

Start/Finish @ The Secret Bar & Kitchen (formerly 360cafe) - SA2 OAY 
(Parking is available opposite in the Recreation Ground car park (SA2 0AU) and there is a bus stop right outside)

Registration Form

Register for the event at http://tiny.cc/hopewalk2021

Please donate what you can and share this page with friends, family and colleagues. 

Any questions please contact Carl: c.k.ely@swansea.ac.uk

The Peoples Kitchen Charity was established in 1985.
Registered charity number 1036149.

They provide friendship and food, 52 weeks a year, 40 hot meals 6 days a week, clothing, sleeping bags, shower facilities and programmes to help towards independent living, combat loneliness and isolation.

They have 200+ volunteers who donate their time free and they have no government grants.

Along with opening their doors they also have a catering van they use 3 half days a week providing food around Newcastle. At the moment they are trying to raise ¬£50,000 to replace their catering van to continue their work in the community and help their friends who are not able to attend the Kitchen.

One day a week the Kitchen opens their doors to invite their friends to karaoke nights, ramblers clubs and more...

Description:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising, it is for a great cause!

My good friend and uncle, Guy, has recently lost his fight with cancer, which has been a great loss to the family. Guy was an avid (and successful) cyclist, and I spent many hours absorbing his advice on bike maintenance, riding technique and stories of his many time trial records at the local club.

I‚Äôll be taking part in memory of Guy, as I know he would have wanted me to be out on the bike, testing out all of his advice!  

The race consists of a 1.9km swim, 90km cycle and a 21km run, all in the worryingly hilly Kent countryside.

Title: Jane's Birthday

Description:
Everyone deserves to feel a sense of belonging; I believe this notion can be found everywhere and anywhere, yet when environments are openly hostile to ones presence, its hard to cultivate this sense of place. This is why the Refugee Community Kitchen is such a valuable initiative, for they are nourishing, nurturing and so unifying displaced people in Northern France, through cooking and distributing hot, culturally sensitive meals in a safe space. 

Active since 2015, the RCK have continued to operate despite the turbulence of camp destruction, police brutality and settlement evictions. The unpredictable Covid-19 restrictions and looming winter months are placing further strains on their mission and to add to the crisis, in early October the French authorities imposed limitations on food distribution within Calais. Clearly, the RCK needs the love and support right now so they may continue providing safe, judgement free spaces where people can gather and tap into a sense of belonging, so vital in these disturbing circumstances. 

In December I will be venturing to Calais to help the RCK continue their phenomenal work. I believe an opportunity to aid hundreds of people, right on our doorstep, who are going without the essentials to human well-being is a privilege not to be passed up. Equally, the profound effect a nourishing meal can have on the body, mind and spirit is truly miraculous, therefore I invite you to open your heart and support my mission, in doing so, the RCK and all the people they serve. 

Contributing could look like diverting your coffee money (or perhaps your lunch money!) towards this fundraiser; sharing this page to family, friends, (or foes...). Equally, if you‚Äôd like to donate kitchen supplies and materials instead of funds, please follow the link bellow to see their ‚ÄòFood/Kitchen Needs List‚Äô and reach out. I will organise the collection, storage and transportation of these life-changing supplies ready for December. 

Any act of kindness would be gratefully received; it means the world that you are on this page right now, ready to make a difference.

Love and Light

Ari <3 


Food/Kitchen Needs List: 

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Byxq9mQj3bPvq5WRxRZHfApBqTGGMVmjxq34Maspqa4/edit

The other charity is the refugee community kitchen which is close to my heart as I was able to volunteer and see the amazing work they do for displaced people in Calais.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Streets of Newcastle, Fairy Tale of Newcastle and Tommy No Shoes The three track CD is just ¬£5 and every penny goes towards helping vulnerable and homeless people in Newcastle.

Our story is below but first some instructions.

The ¬£5 goes direct to The People's Kitchen but you also need to send a stamped addressed envelope  to cover postage   to: Mr T Houghton, 16 Coburg St, Blyth NE24 2EG

A CD should just be a normal first (or second) class (64p/55p) but one I sent recently got snapped in the post so might be best if people  send a jiffy bag (¬£2.85 - second class small parcel) or, even better, a hard backed envelope which would be a large letter 96p first or 75p second.

Our story: 

Punks from all across the region have united together to help the homeless at Christmas with a new version of Ralph McTell‚Äôs hit, Streets of London. (Newcastle) 

The idea of a CD to raise funds for Newcastle‚Äôs People‚Äôs Kitchen was the brainchild of punk couple Tony and Karen Houghton from Blyth. The pair by day are artists and by night adopt the
characters of Sewer Rat and Karen Khaos where they front punk covers band The Pretty Anarchists.  The three tracks on the CD were recorded in two studios‚Äô, Jason Vare‚Äôs Shagnut Studio in Bedlington and at BoomChang Records in Newcastle, which is run by ex Lindisfarne bassist Stephen Cunningham before being duplicated for release by ST UK.

Every aspect of the recording has been carried out free of charge by local businesses and all proceeds from the sale of the CD will go directly to The People‚Äôs Kitchen.

As well as The Pretty Anarchists providing vocals and music for the single, bands from all across the North East provided their singers for the recording.

The bands involved were Peesh (Logoz)
 The V‚Äôs, Zeitgeist 77,  Spitfire Bullets,
 The Band for Disease Control and Prevention, All Out
Attack 

Sponsors

Studio Time - BoomChang Records Newcastle

Studio Time ‚Äì Shagnut Studio Bedlington

Duplication of CD's ST UK

Printing of CD sleeves - Command Print
Amble

Design ‚Äì Sewer Rat Design

PR and media - Highlights PR

Radio support - Radio Northumberland, 

The New Wave with Newman Show with Keith Newman, Punky Paul Storey, Lisa Etherson

Video, Blog and documentary photography - Clemmy
Scotswood and Jill Bee

Media Photography - The Bigger Picture
Agency

This is the seventh two day ride organised for a group of Tyne Valley cyclists. Each year we select a charity and attempt to get fit enough for the two day challenge. Description:
The Killingworth Community Choir have been rehearsing and performing locally for nearly 5 years. When lockdown hit, we decided to meet virtually (thanks to the kind sharing of the St. John's Church zoom account), but for a while we only did quizzes due to the delay issues with zoom. 

Since September we have been singing along on mute while our tireless musical director Selwyn plays the keyboard for us all to sing along. 

We decided to make a recording of Christmas songs as we have missed performing so much. Angela had the clever idea of sharing the recordings on social media along with a Justgiving page to raise the funds that our end of year concert usually generates for charity.

Christine's granddaughter Katy wrote to the committee all the way back in January (before we had heard of lockdown/furlough/COVID etc) to ask that if we raise money this year, please can it be to help people who have become homeless. So this is our way to do this in a socially distanced way.

Description:

At the end of November, 'The Friends of Sherborne Preparatory School' set off on a virtual challenge of 32,400 miles to visit 'Friends Around the Globe'.  Visiting Doha, Singapore, Auckland and Tianjin, China we were able to hold virtual assemblies with our friends and learn about our amazing planet on the way. By logging our walks, runs, cycles, swims, rows and even skiing our amazing Team has propelled our schools Red Dragon across Europe, the Middle East, Asia, the heat of the Australian outback and the bitter
Siberian Winter. In the coming week our intrepid Red Dragon will be coming home after a phenomenal journey without a plane, train or automobile in sight!

Please help us raise ¬£324, 1p/mile, for the amazing Sherborne Community Kitchen who have done such an incredible job looking after our local community in these difficult times.

Title: Operation Red Dragon - 'Friends around the Globe'

Description:
Their mission is to support homeless and disadvantaged people in the Newcastle area, as we have been doing since 1985. 

Their vision is to play a unique role in the City‚Äôs efforts to meet the needs of homeless and vulnerable people



Food is the vital first step in helping our Friends towards a better future. Without The People‚Äôs Kitchen many of our Friends would struggle to afford every day essentials, like a hot meal. We provide 40,000 hot meals a year, from our own premises at the Alison Centre in central Newcastle, and from our mobile kitchen which takes to the streets three times a week. Hot food, clean clothes and warm bedding are a lifeline to our most vulnerable visitors, many of whom suffer from mental illness, physical disability, drug and alcohol misuse, or are rough sleepers.

Title: Christmas Card Alternative

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page! There are a few reasons why I have chosen to do Dry January in aid of The People's Kitchen. Born in Newcastle thirty years ago, the charity aims to combat a growing homelessness and isolation problem that I've seen consistently in my time living there. Through outreach programs that provide food and warmth for the city's displaced, the People's Kitchen is a worthy charity for anyone that has ever imagined what spending a night in the freezing cold would be like. 

I'm personally done with hangovers and my widening overdraft for the moment, (let's see if the two correlate), and I hope that giving up the devil's juice for a month is a good pathway to express my frustration with homelessness we are confronted with all around us, on a daily basis.
Title: Phoebe's Dry January

Description:
Hello everyone,

Thank you for visiting my JustGiving page. 
Much against my better judgement, I will be zip-lining off the iconic Tyne Bridge to raise money to support the fabulous work of the Peoples Kitchen in Newcastle for the amazing work they do with the homeless and vulnerable in this wonderful city of ours.
I am absolutely petrified of heights (I don't even wear heels for flips sake!), so this is a massive personal challenge for me, so as well as raising money for the charity, I will be pushing myself to conquer my own fears. 

So please give if you can, I'll accept anything but buttons!!
Take care of you and thanks again for stopping by.

Love Pam,
With kisses on the bottom xx
Title: Pam's Zipadeedoodah Tyne Bridge Zip Line Challenge

Title: Hornbeam Neighbours Fenwick "Snowman"  Windows

Description:
Make a meal üç≤ Make a donation üí∞ Nominate three friends üë®‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶

This winter, let's stay in and cook up a storm in support of refugees.

To take part all you need to do is make a meal at home (preferably delicious and nutritious!) and to donate some of what you might have otherwise spent out, to the Refugee Community Kitchen.

Once having done that, share a photo of your gorgeous grub on Instagram, tagging @EatInToHelpOut and nominating three friends to do the same. 

We understand these are tough times for all, so whatever you can donate is amazing, no matter how much.


Why we're doing this

We're doing this in support of the brilliant Refugee Community Kitchen who are working hard to provide healthy meals to as many displaced people as they can in the UK and France.

Speaking to their founder, we found out that they need ¬£6,300 every week to serve 10,000 meals, so we've set our target to exactly that and hope that we can stretch it to a whole month if we surpass ¬£6,300 (a whole month would be 44,000 meals!)

If you give just ¬£6, you'll be providing over 9 whole meals!

We all know that food brings people together, and we believe now it can do so more than ever. So get cooking, with family and friends, and let's really show that in the UK we choose love and stand with refugees.

Thank you so so much for your support, and please do SHARE THIS PAGE! You really are making a difference to people's lives.


Refugee Community Kitchen ‚Äì Serving food with dignity

Refugee Community Kitchen serves hot, nourishing meals to displaced people in the UK and France. Since 2015 they have provided over 2.9 million meals with a team of over 18,000 volunteers.

‚ÄúWe give people more than a hot meal, we give them a place to gather and connect. Somewhere to recreate a community - providing space for medical and legal services, safeguarding groups and other support.‚Äù

With Covid-19 having affected everything they do, they need everyone's help more than ever! That's what caused us to come up with this idea, and that's why we need you üôå

Please do take part in Eat In To Help Out, and SHARE THIS PAGE! Your one action can make a genuinely big difference to displaced people's lives. Let's choose love, show that refugees are welcome in the UK, and have some delicious dinners whilst at it. Thank you ü•∞

Title: Mal's doing Movember

Description:
On Saturday the 7th January we are going to host a coffee morning at our house to raise money for the People's Kitchen in Newcastle.

From their site: ' We have been supporting those who need our help in Newcastle for three decades.

Established thanks to one woman‚Äôs determination, our organisation has grown enormously from its humble beginnings under the railway arches at Dean Street, but our philosophy remains the same. We continue to offer clothes, food, warm surroundings, and a warm welcome to anyone that needs our help.'

A brilliant charity who work so hard to provide support to many vulnerable people. Providing food for those in need, providing friendship and also helping them to build happier futures. Please come along and eat cake, or alternatively if you can't make it but would like to donate, you can do so on this page or directly on their website . Thanks you lovely people.

Title: Chloe's Annual coffee morning

Description:
Hey!

My dissertation deadline is just weeks away, and entering probably the busiest time of my life...sounds like the perfect time to do something crazy in the name of charity!

This Saturday I will be taking part in the NUCATS 24-hour charity gameathon. I'll be honest, I'm gonna miss a few hours of it because I already bought tickets to watch Newcastle get thumped by Southampton (just what I need to get my spirits up going into a gaming all-nighter). And I'm playing the drums in church on Sunday morning...hmm...

A few lucky people get paid millions to play video games full-time. I just ask that you give what you can to a fantastic cause, the People's Kitchen Newcastle. As a team we are aiming to raise ¬£3000 for the charity.

It's upsetting walking round Newcastle and seeing the lives that homeless people often choose to live because they have no better option. The People's Kitchen offers warmth and cheer for so many on the streets, and gives us hope that one day the situation will be gone for good.

The plan is to spend the best part of the day (and night) getting my Ultimate Team [Mbemba the Name] from shoddy division 6 up to division 1. If you're really bored enough to want to watch me shout at the Xbox and commentate, I'm thinking to do a Twitch stream too.

It would mean so much to me that you give what you can. Video games are fun but doing it for a cause like this (when I probably should be in the library instead) is so worth it.

Matthew x
Title: Matthew's FIFA Challenge @ NUCATS Gameathon

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Paul's JustGiving page.

Between the 12th and 16th of December Paul will be giving up the comforts of a warm bed and central heating, as he will be spending each night sleeping rough in the doorways of Beamish Museum's Town Street. He is braving the wintry weather to raise money for the People's Kitchen, a Newcastle-based charity who support the city's homeless community by providing vital things, such as hot meals and sleeping bags. More importantly, the People's Kitchen offers friendship and care for some of Newcastle's most vulnerable people.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page, I really
appreciate you taking the time to do so.

As you may all know I'm leaving the University at Christmas to take up a new role in a Primary School in the East of Newcastle. I'm really excited to be taking on this new challenge however I'm equally sad to be saying goodbye to so many great friends and colleagues and an organisation that‚Äôs been a huge part of my life for the last 27 years. It‚Äôs safe to say I will miss you all.


Because I realise I'm one of the lucky people in this world I thought rather than a collection for me, I'd like my leaving gift to be a donation
to the People's Kitchen ‚Äì I‚Äôm sure this will be particularly welcome at this time of year. Founded as a soup kitchen in 1985, The Peoples Kitchen has evolved to offer a range of services to those in
need, they provide up to 100 hot meals a night as well as clothing and
toiletries for those who are less fortunate.

Best wishes

Tracey

Title: Roy's Christmas

Description:
Last Christmas, we asked that no presents were given to the staff. Although we appreciate your generosity, we felt that a donation to local food banks was the best gift that you could give to us. Your response to that request was tremendous. We are very aware that the People‚Äôs Kitchen does some remarkable work and their moto, ‚ÄòWe are not here to see through one another; we are here to see one another through‚Äô, is particularly pertinent at Christmas for people who may be alone and experiencing a difficult time. This Christmas, we also ask that no presents are given to the staff, instead, we wish to support the People‚Äôs Kitchen and have set up a just giving page as we can currently not accept food donations.

The People's Kitchen state that "We can provide a three course meal for just ¬£5 and all of the associated support that goes with it. If you can donate, it would be a tremendous Christmas gift to our Friends.‚Äù

Any Emmaville families (or friends) who would wish to make a monetary donation can do so. 

Everyone at Emmaville and the People's Kitchen thank you all for you kindness and generosity.

Emmaville Primary School
Title: Emmaville's Christmas Gift

Description:
Covid-19 has had a devastating impact on several charities, with Refugee Community Kitchen being one of them. Food and fuel prices have gone up, donations and volunteer numbers have slowed down, and with winter coming hot meals are going to be of increasing importance. With this in mind we have decided to raise some funds for the Kitchen - an incredible charity that do humanitarian work serving hot nutritious meals to displaced people in Northern France as well as homeless people in London and Edinburgh, and have served nearly 3 million hot meals in the past 5 years!

We have chosen the target of collectively running 260 miles during December for this challenge to represent the 26 million refugees that currently exist worldwide.

‚ÄúThe support, sustenance and nourishment these meals and ingredients bring to the people in great need are vital for their day to day survival, the kindness, solidarity and consideration it represents can have an positive effect for a lifetime - together we are stronger.‚Äù - Sam Jones, RCK

Description:
Why should we not celebrate Christmas Jumper day this year! We always do such a good job, there are some fab jumpers. So please dig out your jumper and get in the Christmas Spirit by wearing it on the 9th December for our team event. We will be missing our lovely buffet, but I think a sweet treat will be acceptable to nibble on- go on! 

We always donate to charity for this occasion and usually make a nice donation, we also have on several teams donated to The People's Kitchen in Newcastle to "Feed the Homeless a Christmas Lunch" So I have set this page up to allow anyone who would like to donate to this charity.

It's really easy to do and the funds will go direct to The People's kitchen. 

Thanks for your support. Hohoho
Title: FIS Newcastle Christmas Jumper day

Description:
Since 2015 something extraordinary has happened when thousands of fellow human beings have come close to home needing help, we have got up and helped and whilst doing that we have unintentionally created a new way of helping that‚Äôs accessible to all.

A revolutionary way of helping that provides humanity and nourishment to hungry and vulnerable people creating a connected and kinder world & our  mission is to give highly nutritional food support to displaced people whatever their situation.
Food is a language the crosses all borders
Title: Cook-along with Vetomeato!

Description: Food is a language the crosses all borders. And for the past five years or more, the Refugee Community Kitchen has done incredible work in the camps in Northern France just the other side of the Channel, providing food in incredibly difficult circumstances for displaced people. (I am proud that many of my family have volunteered there; the project was started and is run by Sam Jones, a schoolfriend of my stepson Karim, and his brilliant wife Paola Gallardo. As they put it, 'We are volunteers. We chop. We stir. We serve. We believe food is a human right. Everyone deserves food that we‚Äôd be happy to eat at our own tables.' Since launching, they have served over 2.9 million meals and won a well-deserved Observer Food Monthly Award last year. It's easy to forget right now that ALL charities need our support at this very difficult time, and I am always proud to help these guys. Thanks for donating, if you do...

Description:
I would have definitely been partying with each and everyone one of you , so I‚Äôm asking you to please buy me a drink (or two) on here instead so I can have a virtual party until we can do it for real on the other side!

Your cash will go to the awesome charity I work for, Sue Ryder Wheatfields Hospice. We seriously need help right now more than ever. Our nurses and doctors are putting their lives on the front line everyday to look after people at the end of their lives and support the NHS. If we don‚Äôt get the money we need we have to close, simple as that. 

Thanks everyone love and miss you all, stay safe and see you on the other side xx

CharityName: Refugee Community Kitchen - Prism the Gift Fund
Description:
Greetings family üòä


To celebrate my solar return, I will be volunteering in Calais with RCK to be of service to our displaced brothers and sisters on the border. In 2015, Refugee Community kitchen set up in Calais in response to the humanitarian crisis on our doorstep. You may not see it in the news anymore but there are still vulnerable people living in camps that rely on this service for their daily meals. 


I make this request with love. Minimum donation accepted is ¬£2. If you're struggling to decide on a gift for me then this will be the ideal present! Your gift will go towards purchasing equipment, spices and food ingredients to provide nourishing hot meals. There is no divide between those who serve and those who receive, there is just compassion. Food is a language that crosses all borders ‚ô•Ô∏è 


If you're unable to support this cause financially then please consider giving your time. Now in 2019, Refugee Community Kitchen has expanded their work to supporting refugees and others experiencing food poverty right here in London, UK. This is done with a smile through their outreach kitchens in Camden, Hackney, Bethnal Green, and Brixton. They collectively provide over 2000 meals per month and always welcoming more volunteers. Get in touch via refugeecommunitykitchen@gmail.com.


Sending peace, love and blessings your way. A big thank you in advance. 


Sophia Myambala üåº

(For more information please visit http://www.refugeecommunitykitchen.com/)
Title: For The Love of Food & Community

Description:
Happy Christmas and thank you for visiting my JustGiving page!

Can you believe that teams of about 8 kitchen volunteers using donated ingredients can serve 200+ people 3 meals a day for 10 days? This is what Crisis does at each of their centres around the UK over Christmas.

I was a first time kitchen volunteer three years ago. This time I know what I'm letting myself in for and it is tough my friends!  Crisis works people very hard and expects exceptional standards. I'm doing day long shifts this year and hope that you will feel inspired to support Crisis with a donation.

Your money will contribute to real and long lasting improvements to people's lives.

You see, the Christmas events don't just offer people food and shelter for a week or so, they offer a range of resources to help guests reconnect with family, friends, social and healthcare services and housing.  Crisis also campaigns throughout the year for solutions to the causes of homelessness.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

All face masks should be washed and air dryed before use.  They are not proven to prevent Covid-19 and do not replace a lot of hand washing.

They are part of an ongoing recycling project.  I am definitely not a qualified seamstress but enjoy the process of creating. I have various fabrics but if you have loved old shirts (good ply cotton only) that you would like transferring into a few new face masks, please send them to me with a note.

This is a not for profit project but instead I am asking for a donation to Marie Curie.  We were lucky enough to have had their support during the final stages of my fathers life.  They came like angels in our hour of need and made the end of his life at home as comfortable and as dignified as possible.  As a family, we will always be very grateful.

Title: Team Thykier

Description:
When my family and I visited Zanzibar last year, I met an amazing group of children, who don't have anything other than the smiles on their faces!  I want to switch my birthday presents this year to help raise money to set up a Saturday food kitchen for the towns poorest 100 children.  They need ¬£278 to buy the basic equipment   Instead of birthday presents this year I would love to raise money to help buy the basic equipment.  

**It costs ¬£241 per month to keep it running, so if anyone can spare a small monthly donation then please let my mum know!

A little more about it:

The vision: To make a life changing difference to poor and vulnerable children living in Zanzibar, striving to meet their physical, educational, spiritual and social needs, to help them reach their full potential and become educated, independent young adults who know their self-worth. 

The starting point: Our aim is to start small and build from there. We want to begin by addressing the physical need of food by starting a Saturday Feeding project, initially for 40-60 of the most vulnerable children, rising to 100 kids in the Jambiani area.

To begin with we will rely upon a small group of volunteers, led by Clalence to identify the most needy children, and to deliver the Saturday Club.

As well as the provision of food, the Saturday Club will also begin to meet the social needs of children by providing group activities such as acrobatics and street dancing. 

About my friend Clalence:

Clalence was the very first child we helped in Iringa in 2007!
He lived on and off the streets for many years, but thanks in part to the love and help he received from FISCH, he not only survived but became a man with a heart for helping others in need.In the past few years Clalence set up Move Zanzibar, a non-profit organisation whose vision is to move, educate and motivate the young generation of Zanzibar. The plan is for Move Zanzibar to become a project of FISCH, so we can work together to make a difference for the most vulnerable children in Zanzibar.

FISCH always aim to have a direct impact on the needs of the most
vulnerable children.  There long-term aim is for these children to become self-sufficient, balanced, well rounded and valuable members of the community.
Title: Sebastian Goodall's Birthday

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Words can't express how thankful I am for YouthLine's support.
I am so grateful for them pairing me up with the most kind and caring counsellor, Sue. The support she provided me with over the last few years has made such an impact on my life.

Baking is something I am passionate about, however when I am feeling numb, it can be very hard to motivate myself to do the things I love. Sue reminded me that baking can be a creative outlet and it can also occupy my mind, allowing me to feel more like myself.

So with that in mind I am going to be whisking my way around the kitchen every week, following along with bake off and providing the Staff at my workplace with the tasty bakes. 

Setting this challenge allows me to focus on something once a week, pushing myself to carry on and do something I love, as well as raising money for a special charity.

As YouthLine is a free service, I would like to show my love and appreciation for them, whilst also spreading the word about what they have to offer and breaking the stigma around discussing mental health!

Youthline provides a FREE, confidential counselling service for young people attending secondary school and adults who care for and support young people.

Title: Sam's Global hope Peru community work

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page

Sadly we found out recently one of our valued customers,passed away.

In memory of Debra Holmes,who sadly lost her fight against breast cancer recently.

Debra had a real zest for life,and loved the period in which we concentrate our restorations on, the 1950s.

A school teacher for 40 years who had influenced many a young mind,also a member of Macmillan for years raising funds herself.

She had a large circle of friends and loving family. 

I suggested it maybe a lovely idea to run a draw to win Debra's prized pieces of furniture,that she loved so much,which her friends and family have kindly agreed too.

So that's the idea.These pieces have all been previously restored by us,at Resto-Worx.

These are namely a rare and much sought after Maidsaver kitchen larder,with beautiful sun ray glass.

A Remploy folding tea trolley on castors and a Fleetwood double wall cupboard with raindrop glass sliding doors.

3 beautiful functional pieces.

We are asking for a minimum donation of ¬£5,but please give as much as you can afford for this worthy cause.

Someone will win these wonderful pieces.Please bear in mind these pieces are not new and although restored will have wear commensurate with useage.

We have also arranged free Uk delivery,some restrictions may apply on geographic area.

Please go to www.facebook.com/Resto-Worx for full details on the draw.

Title: David's page

Description:
Hadrian‚Äôs Wall Path

When the Roman Empire decided to build a wall to keep the marauding Pictish Scots out of northern England, they likely didn‚Äôt consider that their handiwork would one day form the backdrop for one of the country‚Äôs finest walks. Spanning 135km from Bowness-on-Solway in Cumbria, to appropriately named Wallsend in Tyne and Wear, this moderately challenging National Trail fuses bracing hiking with the cultural heritage for which the UK is famous. Large sections of the wall remain intact, along with a fine museum at the painstakingly excavated Roman fort of Segedunum

 

While serving I won Exercise Yorkshire Canter twice in the eighties, covering 100 miles in 24hrs, carrying full kit and Rifle, changed my socks after the first 60 miles whether they needed it or not, when you do something such as this you just keep your body moving, there's plenty of time to rest at the finish point. I Completed an 85 km X Country Ski marathon in 7hrs 01 min and even managed to run the B.F.T. 1 &1/2 mile backwards in under 11 &1/2 mins, I am coming out of retirement to complete this challenge because I want to "do" something to Support 'The Rifles Charities- Care for Casualties'

 

I want to raise as much money as possible because they are commited to:

1. Caring for members of the 'Rifles family', both those serving and their families.

2. Offer enduring support to injured Soldiers and their families.

3.Continue to fundraise to ensure the Soldiers and their families receive the highest quality care as possible.

This is why I need your help in sponsoring me, any donation will help in maintaining the high care and support that 'Care for Casualties' currently gives out.

THE CHALLENGE

I am going to walk Hadrians wall from Solway Firth in the West to Wallsend in the East, total mileage 84 miles, over undulating ground, unaided, with nil costs, eat on the hoof and complete it in 2 days, oh ! and I will be carrying a kitchen sink on my back and hoping to get sponsorship from B&Q

I have today 9/7/10 had confirmation that B&Q are going to sponsor me and now have the Kitchen sink complete with taps etc. Once I have secured it to my rucksack I will post more photographs wearing the bright orange B&Q apron with my name on it and of course the much sought after Rifles Regimental T Shirt.

Thanks to everyone who has sponsored me so far

I have 50 Rifles wrist bands to give out to people I meet along the wall & a Rifles pennant to fly off my rucksack.

Fund raising going well, big effort being carried out by B&Q in Stockton to raise as much cash in the store.

Once again big thanks to all of you for your kind donations.

Tuesday 2nd August 2010

Anyone watching this page will know there are just a few days to go before I set off and a Kitchen sink will be seen being carried along Hadrians wall for probably the first time in its History, wonder what the Romans would think of it ?

Thursday 5th August

I am so grateful for the kind donations that are still coming in with just a couple of days to go,

Thanks to everyone and please tell your friends so that together we can pledge as much money as possible to this worthwhile cause.

Coco

Friday 6th August- 1645hrs

In a little over 12hrs I will be setting off from Bowness on Solway, East Bound, hoping to collect sponsors along the wall, weather will be ideal for the weekend, Sunshine with Showers, post photos Monday once again big thanks for the support from everyone,

Regards,

Coco

Please see press report below

http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/north-east-news/evening-chronicle-news/2010/08/10/ex-soldier-takes-kitchen-sink-on-charity-trek-72703-27032431/

 

Sunday 15th August

Thank you on behalf of the RIFLES REGIMENT for the continued support, donations coming in every day for this worthwhile Charity.

Coco

 

Wednesday 18th August

I am replying to all that leave their e mail Address to say thank you for your donation and words of encouragement, can't thank you all enough.

Has anyone out there got any suggestions as to what I could do with my Sink, probably the only one in the World that has travelled along that path, raised so much money for so many and after all it has had only one careful owner.

E BAY ???????

Tuesday 31st August 2010

Thank you to everyone supporting this great charity, still getting donations from as far away as Canada and Australia,

Regards,

Coco

Thursday 2nd September 2010

My story has now been put on the Rifles Care for Casualties web site, please see the news page to see how the idea of carrying a sink along Hadrians Wall came about and the ups and downs of this incredible but very funny journey and how I raised shed loads of money just on the Wall alone.

 

Monday 6th September 2010

I have today been approached by a Magazine to have my story entered with the understanding that all of the fee money that I will receive is paid directly into the Rifles Care for Casualties Charity.
